sp.p: This, then, was my question just now: How should we express ourselves in speaking about them when an arithmetician undertakes to count or a man of letters to read something? In such a case shall we say that although he knows he sets himself to learn again from himself that which he knows?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But that is extraordinary, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But shall we say that he is going to read or count that which he does not know, when we have granted that he knows all letters and all numbers?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But that too is absurd.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we then say that words are nothing to us, if it amuses anyone to drag the expressions “know” and “learn” one way and another, but since we set up the distinction that it is one thing to possess knowledge and another thing to have it, we affirm that it is impossible not to possess what one possesses, so that it never happens that a man does not know that which he knows, but that it is possible to conceive a false opinion about it? For it is possible to have not the knowledge of this thing, but some other knowledge instead, when in hunting for some one kind of knowledge, as the various kinds fly about, he makes a mistake and catches one instead of another; so in one example he thought eleven was twelve, because he caught the knowledge of twelve, which was within him, instead of that of eleven, caught a ringdove, as it were, instead of a pigeon.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is reasonable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But when he catches the knowledge he intends to catch, he is not deceived and has true opinion, and so true and false opinion exist and none of the things which formerly annoyed us interferes? Perhaps you will agree to this; or what will you do?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for we have got rid of our difficulty about men not knowing that which they know; for we no longer find ourselves not possessing that which we possess, whether we are deceived about anything or not. However, another more dreadful disaster seems to be coming in sight.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What disaster?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If the interchange of kinds of knowledge should ever turn out to be false opinion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is it not the height of absurdity, in the first place for one who has knowledge of something to be ignorant of this very thing, not through ignorance but through his knowledge; secondly, for him to be of opinion that this thing is something else and something else is this thing—for the soul, when knowledge has come to it, to know nothing and be ignorant of all things? For by this argument there is nothing to prevent ignorance from coming to us and making us know something and blindness from making us see, if knowledge is ever to make us ignorant.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps, Socrates, we were not right in making the birds represent kinds of knowledge only, but we ought to have imagined kinds of ignorance also flying about in the soul with the others; then the hunter would catch sometimes knowledge and sometimes ignorance of the same thing, and through the ignorance he would have false, but through the knowledge true opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is not easy, Theaetetus, to refrain from praising you. However, examine your suggestion once more. Let it be as you say: the man who catches the ignorance will, you say, have false opinion. Is that it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But surely he will not also think that he has false opinion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, but true opinion, and will have the attitude of knowing that about which he is deceived.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence he will fancy that he has caught, and has, knowledge, not ignorance.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, after our long wanderings, we have come round again to our first difficulty. For the real reasoner will laugh and say, “Most excellent Sirs, does a man who knows both knowledge and ignorance think that one of them, which he knows, is another thing which he knows; or, knowing neither of them, is he of opinion that one, which he does not know, is another thing which he does not know; or, knowing one and not the other, does he think that the one he does not know is the one he knows; or that the one he knows is the one he does not know? Or will you go on and tell me that there are kinds of knowledge of the kinds of knowledge and of ignorance, and that he who possesses these kinds of knowledge and has enclosed them in some sort of other ridiculous aviaries or waxen figments, knows them, so long as he possesses them, even if he has them not at hand in his soul? And in this fashion are you going to be compelled to trot about endlessly in the same circle without making any progress?” What shall we reply to this, Theaetetus?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By Zeus, Socrates, I don't know what to say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, my boy, is the argument right in rebuking us and in pointing out that we were wrong to abandon knowledge and seek first for false opinion? It is impossible to know the latter until we have adequately comprehended the nature of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: As the case now stands, Socrates, we cannot help thinking as you say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To begin, then, at the beginning once more, what shall we say knowledge is? For surely we are not going to give it up yet, are we?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not by any means, unless, that is, you give it up.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Tell us, then, what definition will make us contradict ourselves least.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The one we tried before, Socrates; at any rate, I have nothing else to offer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What one?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That knowledge is true opinion; for true opinion is surely free from error and all its results are fine and good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The man who was leading the way through the river,A man who was leading the way through a river was asked if the water was deep. He replied AU)TO\ DEI/CEI, “the event itself will show” (i.e. you can find out by trying). The expression became proverbial. Theaetetus, said: “The result itself will show;” and so in this matter, if we go on with our search, perhaps the thing will turn up in our path and of itself reveal the object of our search; but if we stay still, we shall discover nothing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right; let us go on with our investigation.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, this at least calls for slight investigation; for you have a whole profession which declares that true opinion is not knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so? What profession is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The profession of those who are greatest in wisdom, who are called orators and lawyers; for they persuade men by the art which they possess, not teaching them, but making them have whatever opinion they like. Or do you think there are any teachers so clever as to be able, in the short time allowed by the water-clock,The length of speeches in the Athenian law courts was limited by a water-clock. satisfactorily to teach the judges the truth about what happened to people who have been robbed of their money or have suffered other acts of violence, when there were no eyewitnesses?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I certainly do not think so; but I think they can persuade them.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And persuading them is making them have an opinion, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then when judges are justly persuaded about matters which one can know only by having seen them and in no other way, in such a case, judging of them from hearsay, having acquired a true opinion of them, they have judged without knowledge, though they are rightly persuaded, if the judgement they have passed is correct, have they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, my friend, if true opinion and knowledge were the same thing in law courts, the best of judges could never have true opinion without knowledge; in fact, however, it appears that the two are different.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Oh yes, I remember now, Socrates, having heard someone make the distinction, but I had forgotten it. He said that knowledge was true opinion accompanied by reason, but that unreasoning true opinion was outside of the sphere of knowledge; and matters of which there is not a rational explanation are unknowable—yes, that is what he called them—and those of which there is are knowable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I am glad you mentioned that. But tell us how he distinguished between the knowable and the unknowable, that we may see whether the accounts that you and I have heard agree.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But I do not know whether I can think it out; but if someone else were to make the statement of it, I think I could follow.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Listen then, while I relate it to you—“a dream for a dream.” I in turn used to imagine that I heard certain persons say that the primary elements of which we and all else are composed admit of no rational explanation; for each alone by itself can only be named, and no qualification can be added, neither that it is nor that it is not, for that would at once be adding to it existence or non-existence, whereas we must add nothing to it, if we are to speak of that itself alone. Indeed, not even “itself” or “that” or “each” or “alone” or “this” or anything else of the sort, of which there are many, must be added; for these are prevalent terms which are added to all things indiscriminately and are different from the things to which they are added; but if it were possible to explain an element, and it admitted of a rational explanation of its own, it would have to be explained apart from everything else. But in fact none of the primal elements can be expressed by reason; they can only be named, for they have only a name; but the things composed of these are themselves complex, and so their names are complex and form a rational explanation; for the combination of names is the essence of reasoning. Thus the elements are not objects of reason or of knowledge, but only of perception, whereas the combinations of them are objects of knowledge and expression and true opinion. When therefore a man acquires without reasoning the true opinion about anything, his mind has the truth about it, but has no knowledge; for he who cannot give and receive a rational explanation of a thing is without knowledge of it; but when he has acquired also a rational explanation he may possibly have become all that I have said and may now be perfect in knowledge. Is that the version of the dream you have heard, or is it different?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That was it exactly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you satisfied, then, and do you state it in this way, that true opinion accompanied by reason is knowledge?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Can it be, Theaetetus, that we now, in this casual manner, have found out on this day what many wise men have long been seeking and have grown grey in the search?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I, at any rate, Socrates, think our present statement is good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Probably this particular statement is so; for what knowledge could there still be apart from reason and right opinion? One point, however, in what has been said is unsatisfactory to me.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What point?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Just that which seems to be the cleverest; the assertion that the elements are unknowable and the class of combinations is knowable.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Is that not right?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We are sure to find out, for we have as hostages the examples which he who said all this used in his argument.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What examples?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The elements in writing, the letters of the alphabet, and their combinations, the syllables*STOIXEI=ON and SULLABH/ originally general terms for element and combination, became the common words for letter and syllable.; or do you think the author of the statements we are discussing had something else in view?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No; those are what he had in view.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, take them up and examine them, or rather, let us examine ourselves and see whether it was in accordance with this theory, or not, that we learned letters. First then, the syllables have a rational explanation, but the letters have not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think so, too, decidedly. Now if anyone should ask about the first syllable of Socrates; “Theaetetus, tell me, what is SO?” What would you reply?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I should say “S and O.”

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This, then, is your explanation of the syllable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come now, in the same manner give me the explanation of the S.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How can one give any elements of an element? For really, Socrates, the S is a voiceless letter,The distinction here made is that which we make between vowels and consonants. The seven Greek vowels are A, E, H, I, O, U, W called FWNH/ENTA. a mere noise, as of the tongue hissing; B again has neither voice nor noise, nor have most of the other letters; and so it is quite right to say that they have no explanation, seeing that the most distinct of them, the seven vowels, have only voice, but no explanation whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In this point, then, my friend, it would seem that we have reached a right conclusion about knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think we have.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But have we been right in laying down the principle that whereas the letter is unknowable, yet the syllable is knowable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Probably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, shall we say that the syllable is the two letters, or, if there be more than two, all of them, or is it a single concept that has arisen from their combination?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think we mean all the letters it contains.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now take the case of two, S and O. The two together are the first syllable of my name. He who knows it knows the two letters, does he not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: He knows, that is, the S and the O.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How is that? He is ignorant of each, and knowing neither of them he knows them both?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is monstrous and absurd, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And yet if a knowledge of each letter is necessary before one can know both, he who is ever to know a syllable must certainly know the letters first, and so our fine theory will have run away and vanished!

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And very suddenly, too.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for we are not watching it carefully. Perhaps we ought to have said that the syllable is not the letters, but a single concept that has arisen from them, having a single form of its own, different from the letters.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly; and perhaps that will be better than the other way.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us look into that; we must not give up in such unmanly fashion a great and impressive theory.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, we must not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let it be, then, as we say now, that the syllable or combination is a single form arising out of the several conjoined elements, and that it is the same in words and in all other things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Therefore there must be no parts of it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because if there are parts of anything, the whole must inevitably be all the parts; or do you assert also that the whole that has arisen out of the parts is a single concept different from all the parts?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you then say that all and the whole are the same, or that each of the two is different from the other?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I am not sure; but you tell me to answer boldly, so I take the risk and say that they are different.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Your boldness, Theaetetus, is right; but whether your answer is so remains to be seen.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, certainly, we must see about that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The whole, then, according to our present view, would differ from all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How about this? Is there any difference between all in the plural and all in the singular? For instance, if we say one, two, three, four, five, six, or twice three, or three times two, or four and two, or three and two and one, are we in all these forms speaking of the same or of different numbers?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of the same.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is, of six?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in each form of speech we have spoken of all the six?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again do we not speak of one thing when we speak of them all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is, of six?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in all things that are made up of number, we apply the same term to all in the plural and all in the singular?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Here is another way of approaching the matter. The number of the fathom and the fathom are the same, are they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And of the furlong likewise.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the number of the army is the same as the army, and all such cases are alike? In each of them all the number is all the thing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is the number of each anything but the parts of each?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Everything that has parts, accordingly, consists of parts, does it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But we are agreed that the all must be all the parts if all the number is to be the all.Cf. Plat. Theaet. 204b

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the whole does not consist of parts, for if it consisted of all the parts it would be the all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That seems to be true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is a part a part of anything in the world but the whole?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, of the all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are putting up a brave fight, Theaetetus. But is not the all precisely that of which nothing is wanting?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not just this same thing, from which nothing whatsoever is lacking, a whole? For that from which anything is lacking is neither a whole nor all, which have become identical simultaneously and for the same reason.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think now that there is no difference between all and whole.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We were saying, were we not, that if there are parts of anything, the whole and all of it will be all the parts?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Once more, then, as I was trying to say just now, if the syllable is not the letters, does it not follow necessarily that it contains the letters, not as parts of it, or else that being the same as the letters, it is equally knowable with them?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It does.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it was in order to avoid this that we assumed that it was different from them?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, if the letters are not parts of the syllable, can you mention any other things which are parts of it, but are not the lettersThe reader is reminded that words STOIXEI=ON and SULLABH/ have the meanings “element” and “combination” as well as “letter” and “syllable.” of it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not. For if I grant that there are parts of the syllable, it would be ridiculous to give up the letters and look for other things as parts.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Without question, then, Theaetetus, the syllable would be, according to our present view, some indivisible concept.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you remember, then, my friend, that we admitted a little while ago, on what we considered good grounds, that there can be no rational explanation of the primary elements of which other things are composed, because each of them, when taken by itself, is not composite, and we could not properly apply to such an element even the expression “be” or “this,” because these terms are different and alien, and for this reason it is irrational and unknowable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not this the sole reason why it is single in form and indivisible? I can see no other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: There is no other to be seen.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the syllable falls into the same class with the letter, if it has no parts and is a single form?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, unquestionably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If, then, the syllable is a plurality of letters and is a whole of which the letters are parts, the syllables and the letters are equally knowable and expressible, if all the parts were found to be the same as the whole.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if one and indivisible, then syllable and likewise letter are equally irrational and unknowable; for the same cause will make them so.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I cannot dispute it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we must not accept the statement of any one who says that the syllable is knowable and expressible, but the letter is not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, not if we are convinced by our argument.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But would you not rather accept the opposite belief, judging by your own experience when you were learning to read?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What experience?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In learning, you were merely constantly trying to distinguish between the letters both by sight and by hearing, keeping each of them distinct from the rest, that you might not be disturbed by their sequence when they were spoken or written.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in the music school was not perfect attainment the ability to follow each note and tell which string produced it; and everyone would agree that the notes are the elements of music?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is all true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if we are to argue from the elements and combinations in which we ourselves have experience to other things in general, we shall say that the elements as a class admit of a much clearer knowledge than the compounds and of a knowledge that is much more important for the complete attainment of each branch of learning, and if anyone says that the compound is by its nature knowable and the element unknowable, we shall consider that he is, intentionally or unintentionally, joking.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Still other proofs of this might be brought out, I think; but let us not on that account lose sight of the question before us, which is: What is meant by the doctrine that the most perfect knowledge arises from the addition of rational explanation to true opinion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, we must not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now what are we intended to understand by “rational explanation”? I think it means one of three things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The first would be making one's own thought clear through speech by means of verbs and nouns, imaging the opinion in the stream that flows through the lips, as in a mirror or water. Do you not think the rational explanation is something of that sort?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I do. At any rate, we say that he who does that speaks or explains.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, that is a thing that anyone can do sooner or later; he can show what he thinks about anything, unless he is deaf or dumb from the first; and so all who have any right opinion will be found to have it with the addition of rational explanation, and there will henceforth be no possibility of right opinion apart from knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us not, therefore, carelessly accuse him of talking nonsense who gave the definition of knowledge which we are now considering; for perhaps that is not what he meant. He may have meant that each person if asked about anything must be able in reply to give his questioner an account of it in terms of its elements.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: As for example, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: As, for example, Hesiod, speaking of a wagon, says, “a hundred pieces of wood in a wagon.”Hes. WD 456 Now I could not name the pieces, nor, I fancy, could you; but if we were asked what a wagon is, we should be satisfied if we could say “wheels, axle, body, rims, yoke.”

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But he, perhaps, would think we were ridiculous, just as he would if, on being asked about your name, we should reply by telling the syllables, holding a right opinion and expressing correctly what we have to say, but should think we were grammarians and as such both possessed and were expressing as grammarians would the rational explanation of the name Theaetetus. He would say that it is impossible for anyone to give a rational explanation of anything with knowledge, until he gives a complete enumeration of the elements, combined with true opinion. That, I believe, is what was said before.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So, too, he would say that we have right opinion about a wagon, but that he who can give an account of its essential nature in terms of those one hundred parts has by this addition added rational explanation to true opinion and has acquired technical knowledge of the essential nature of a wagon, in place of mere opinion, by describing the whole in terms of its elements.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Do you agree to that, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If you, my friend, agree to it and accept the view that orderly description in terms of its elements is a rational account of anything, but that description in terms of syllables or still larger units is irrational, tell me so, that we may examine the question.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly I accept it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you accept it in the belief that anyone has knowledge of anything when he thinks that the same element is a part sometimes of one thing and sometimes of another or when he is of opinion that the same thing has as a part of it sometimes one thing and sometimes another?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all, by Zeus.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you forget that when you began to learn to read you and the others did just that?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Do you mean when we thought that sometimes one letter and sometimes another belonged to the same syllable, and when we put the same letter sometimes into the proper syllable and sometimes into another?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is what I mean.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By Zeus, I do not forget, nor do I think that those have knowledge who are in that condition.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Take an example: When at such a stage in his progress a person in writing “Theaetetus” thinks he ought to write, and actually does write, TH and E, and again in trying to write “Theodorus” thinks he ought to write, and does write, T and E, shall we say that he knows the first syllable of your names?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, we just now agreed that a person in such a condition has not yet gained knowledge.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then there is nothing to prevent the same person from being in that condition with respect to the second and third and fourth syllables?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, nothing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, in that case, he has in mind the orderly description in terms of letters, and will write “Theaetetus” with right opinion, when he writes the letters in order?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But he is still, as we say, without knowledge, though he has right opinion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, but with his opinion he has rational explanation; for he wrote with the method in terms of letters in his mind, and we agreed that that was rational explanation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There is, then, my friend, a combination of right opinion with rational explanation, which cannot as yet properly be called knowledge?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: There is not much doubt about it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So it seems that the perfectly true definition of knowledge, which we thought we had, was but a golden dream. Or shall we wait a bit before we condemn it? Perhaps the definition to be adopted is not this, but the remaining one of the three possibilities one of which we said must be affirmed by anyone who asserts that knowledge is right opinion combined with rational explanation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I am glad you called that to mind. For there is still one left. The first was a kind of vocal image of the thought, the second the orderly approach to the whole through the elements, which we have just been discussing, and what is the third?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is just the definition which most people would give, that knowledge is the ability to tell some characteristic by which the object in question differs from all others.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: As an example of the method, what explanation can you give me, and of what thing?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: As an example, if you like, take the sun: I think it is enough for you to be told that it is the brightest of the heavenly bodies that revolve about the earth.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Understand why I say this. It is because, as we were just saying, if you get hold of the distinguishing characteristic by which a given thing differs from the rest, you will, as some say, get hold of the definition or explanation of it; but so long as you cling to some common quality, your explanation will pertain to all those objects to which the common quality belongs.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I understand; and it seems to me that it is quite right to call that kind a rational explanation or definition.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he who possesses right opinion about anything and adds thereto a comprehension of the difference which distinguishes it from other things will have acquired knowledge of that thing of which he previously had only opinion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is what we affirm.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Theaetetus, now that I have come closer to our statement, I do not understand it at all. It is like coming close to a scene-painting.In which perspective is the main thing. While I stood off at a distance, I thought there was something in it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you if I can. Assume that I have right opinion about you; if I add the explanation or definition of you, then I have knowledge of you, otherwise I have merely opinion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But explanation was, we agreed, the interpretation of your difference.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then so long as I had merely opinion, I did not grasp in my thought any of the points in which you differ from others?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Therefore I was thinking of some one of the common traits which you possess no more than other men.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You must have been.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For heaven's sake! How in the world could I in that case have any opinion about you more than about anyone else? Suppose that I thought “That is Theaetetus which is a man and has nose and eyes and mouth” and so forth, mentioning all the parts. Can this thought make me think of Theaetetus any more than of Theodorus or of the meanest of the Mysians,The Mysians were despised as especially effeminate and worthless as the saying is?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if I think not only of a man with nose and eyes, but of one with snub nose and protruding eyes, shall I then have an opinion of you any more than of myself and all others like me?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No; I fancy Theaetetus will not be the object of opinion in me until this snubnosedness of yours has stamped and deposited in my mind a memorial different from those of the other examples of snubnosedness that I have seen, and the other traits that make up your personality have done the like. Then that memorial, if I meet you again tomorrow, will awaken my memory and make me have right opinion about you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then right opinion also would have to do with differences in any given instance?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: At any rate, it seems so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what becomes of the addition of reason or explanation to right opinion? For if it is defined as the addition of an opinion of the way in which a given thing differs from the rest, it is an utterly absurd injunction.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When we have a right opinion of the way in which certain things differ from other things, we are told to acquire a right opinion of the way in which those same things differ from other things! On this plan the twirling of a scytaleASKUTA/LH was a staff, especially a staff about which a strip of leather was rolled, on which dispatches were so written that when unrolled they were illegible until rolled again upon another staff of the same size and shape. or a pestle or anything of the sort would be as nothing compared with this injunction. It might more justly be called a blind man's giving directions; for to command us to acquire that which we already have, in order to learn that of which we already have opinion, is very like a man whose sight is mightily darkened.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell me now, what did you intend to say when you asked the question a while ago?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If, my boy, the command to add reason or explanation means learning to know and not merely getting an opinion about the difference, our splendid definition of knowledge would be a fine affair! For learning to know is acquiring knowledge, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, it seems, if asked, “What is knowledge?” our leader will reply that it is right opinion with the addition of a knowledge of difference; for that would, according to him, be the addition of reason or explanation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is utterly silly, when we are looking for a definition of knowledge, to say that it is right opinion with knowledge, whether of difference or of anything else whatsoever. So neither perception, Theaetetus, nor true opinion, nor reason or explanation combined with true opinion could be knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are we then, my friend, still pregnant and in travail with knowledge, or have we brought forth everything?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we have, and, by Zeus, Socrates, with your help I have already said more than there was in me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then does our art of midwifery declare to us that all the offspring that have been born are mere wind-eggs and not worth rearing?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It does, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If after this you ever undertake to conceive other thoughts, Theaetetus, and do conceive, you will be pregnant with better thoughts than these by reason of the present search, and if you remain barren, you will be less harsh and gentler to your associates, for you will have the wisdom not to think you know that which you do not know. So much and no more my art can accomplish; nor do I know aught of the things that are known by others, the great and wonderful men who are today and have been in the past. This art, however, both my mother and I received from God, she for women and I for young and noble men and for all who are fair. And now I must go to the Porch of the King, to answer to the suit which MeletusMeletus was one of those who brought the suit which led to the condemnation and death of Socrates. has brought against me. But in the morning, Theodorus, let us meet here again.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: According to our yesterday's agreement, Socrates, we have come ourselves, as we were bound to do, and we bring also this man with us; he is a stranger from Elea, one of the followers of Parmenides and Zeno, and a real philosopher.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you not unwittingly bringing, as Homer says, some god, and no mere stranger, Theodorus? He says that the gods, and especially the god of strangers, enter into companionship with men who have a share of due reverenceA modified quotation from Hom. Od. 9.271; Hom. Od. 17.485-7 and that they behold the deeds, both violent and righteous,Cf. Od. 17.485-7 of mankind. So perhaps this companion of yours may be one of the higher powers, who comes to watch over and refute us because we are worthless in argument—a kind of god of refutation.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: No, Socrates, that is not the stranger's character; he is more reasonable than those who devote themselves to disputation. And though I do not think he is a god at all, I certainly do think he is divine, for I give that epithet to all philosophers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And rightly, my friend. However, I fancy it is not much easier, if I may say so, to recognize this class, than that of the gods. For these men—I mean those who are not feignedly but really philosophers—appear disguised in all sorts of shapes,Cf. Hom. Od. 17.485-7. thanks to the ignorance of the rest of mankind, and “visit the cities,”Hom. Od. 17.485-7 beholding from above the life of those below, and they seem to some to be of no worth and to others to be worth everything. And sometimes they appear disguised as statesmen and sometimes as sophists, and sometimes they may give some people the impression that they are altogether mad. But I should like to ask our stranger here, if agreeable to him, what people in his country thought about these matters, and what names they used.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: What matters do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Sophist, statesman, philosopher.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: What particular difficulty and what kind of difficulty in regard to them is it about which you had in mind to ask?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is this: Did they consider all these one, or two, or, as there are three names, did they divide them into three classes and ascribe to each a class, corresponding to a single name?

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: I think he has no objection to talking about them. What do you say, stranger?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Just what you did, Theodorus; for I have no objection, and it is not difficult to say that they considered them three. But it is no small or easy task to define clearly the nature of each.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: The fact is, Socrates, that by chance you have hit upon a question very like what we happened to be asking him before we came here; and he made excuses to us then, as he does now to you; though he admits that he has heard it thoroughly discussed and remembers what he heard.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In that case, stranger, do not refuse us the first favor we have asked; but just tell us this: Do you generally prefer to expound in a long uninterrupted speech of your own whatever you wish to explain to anyone, or do you prefer the method of questions? I was present once when Parmenides employed the latter method and carried on a splendid discussion. I was a young man then, and he was very old.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The method of dialogue, Socrates, is easier with an interlocutor who is tractable and gives no trouble; but otherwise I prefer the continuous speech by one person.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, you may choose whomever you please of those present; they will all respond pleasantly to you; but if you take my advice you will choose one of the young fellows, Theaetetus here, or any of the others who suits you.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Socrates, this is the first time I have come among you, and I am somewhat ashamed, instead of carrying on the discussion by merely giving brief replies to your questions, to deliver an extended, long drawn out speech, either as an address of my own or in reply to another, as if I were giving an exhibition; but I must, for really the present subject is not what one might expect from the form of the question, but is a matter for very long speech. On the other hand it seems unfriendly and discourteous to refuse a favor to you and these gentlemen, especially when you have spoken as you did. As for Theaetetus I accept him most willingly as interlocutor in view of my previous conversation with him and of your present recommendation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But, stranger, by taking this course and following Socrates's suggestion will you please the others too?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am afraid there is nothing more to be said about that, Theaetetus; but from now on, my talk will, I fancy, be addressed to you. And if you get tired and are bored by the length of the talk, do not blame me, but these friends of yours.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Oh, no, I do not think I shall get tired of it so easily, but if such a thing does happen, we will call in this Socrates, the namesake of the other Socrates; he is of my own age and my companion in the gymnasium, and is in the habit of working with me in almost everything.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well; you will follow your own devices about that as the discussion proceeds; but now you and I must investigate in common, beginning first, as it seems to me, with the sophist, and must search out and make plain by argument what he is. For as yet you and I have nothing in common about him but the name; but as to the thing to which we give the name, we may perhaps each have a conception of it in our own minds; however, we ought always in every instance to come to agreement about the thing itself by argument rather than about the mere name without argument. But the tribe which we now intend to search for, the sophist, is not the easiest thing in the world to catch and define, and everyone has agreed long ago that if investigations of great matters are to be properly worked out we ought to practice them on small and easier matters before attacking the very greatest. So now, Theaetetus, this is my advice to ourselves, since we think the family of sophists is troublesome and hard to catch, that we first practise the method of hunting in something easier, unless you perhaps have some simpler way to suggest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I have not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we take some lesser thing and try to use it as a pattern for the greater?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, what example can we set before us which is well known and small, but no less capable of definition than any of the greater things? Say an angler; is he not known to all and unworthy of any great interest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I hope he offers us a method and is capable of a definition not unsuitable to our purpose.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That would be good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come now; let us begin with him in this way: Tell me, shall we say that he is a man with an art, or one without an art, but having some other power?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not one without an art.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But of all arts there are, speaking generally, two kinds?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Agriculture and all kinds of care of any living beings, and that which has to do with things which are put together or molded (utensils we call them), and the art of imitation—all these might properly be called by one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so, and what is the name?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When anyone brings into being something which did not previously exist, we say that he who brings it into being produces it and that which is brought into being is produced.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now all the arts which we have just mentioned direct their energy to production.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, call these collectively the productive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And after this comes the whole class of learning and that of acquiring knowledge, and money making, and fighting, and hunting. None of these is creative, but they are all engaged in coercing, by deeds or words, things which already exist and have been produced, or in preventing others from coercing them; therefore all these divisions together might very properly be called acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that would be proper.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since acquisitive and productive art comprise all the arts, in which, Theaetetus, shall we place the art of angling?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In acquisitive art, clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And are there not two classes of acquisitive art—one the class of exchange between voluntary agents by means of gifts and wages and purchases, and the other, which comprises all the rest of acquisitive art, and, since it coerces either by word or deed, might be called coercive?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It appears so, at any rate, from what you have said.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, shall we not divide coercive art into two parts?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By calling all the open part of it fighting and all the secret part hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it would be unreasonable not to divide hunting into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Say how it can be done.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By dividing it into the hunting of the lifeless and of the living.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly, if both exist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of course they exist. And we must pass over the hunting of lifeless things, which has no name, with the exception of some kinds of diving and the like, which are of little importance; but the hunting of living things we will call animal-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And two classes of animal-hunting might properly be made, one (and this is divided under many classes and names) the hunting of creatures that go on their feet, land-animal hunting, and the other that of swimming creatures, to be called, as a whole, water-animal hunting?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And of swimming creatures we see that one tribe is winged and the other is in the water?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the hunting of winged creatures is called, as a whole, fowling.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the hunting of water creatures goes by the general name of fishing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And might I not divide this kind of hunting into two principal divisions?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What divisions?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one carries on the hunt by means of enclosures merely, the other by a blow.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean, and how do you distinguish the two?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: As regards the first, because whatever surrounds anything and encloses it so as to constrain it is properly called an enclosure.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: May not, then, wicker baskets and seines and snares and nets and the like be called enclosures?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we will call this division hunting by enclosures, or something of that sort.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the other, which is done with a blow, by means of hooks and three pronged spears, we must now—to name it with a single word— call striking; or could a better name be found, Theaetetus?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Never mind the name; that will do well enough.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the kind of striking which takes place at night by the light of a fire is, I suppose, called by the hunters themselves fire-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that which belongs to the daytime is, as a whole, barb-hunting, since the spears, as well as the hooks, are tipped with barbs.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is so called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then of striking which belongs to barb-hunting, that part which proceeds downward from above, is called, because tridents are chiefly used in it, tridentry, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, some people, at any rate, call it so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there still remains, I may say, only one further kind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The kind that is characterized by the opposite sort of blow, which is practised with a hook and strikes, not any chance part of the body of the fishes, as tridents do, but only the head and mouth of the fish caught, and proceeds from below upwards, being pulled up by twigs and rods. By what name, Theaetetus, shall we say this ought to be called?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think our search is now ended and we have found the very thing we set before us a while ago as necessary to find.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, you and I are not only agreed about the name of angling, but we have acquired also a satisfactory definition of the thing itself. For of art as a whole, half was acquisitive, and of the acquisitive, half was coercive, and of the coercive, half was hunting, and of hunting, half was animal hunting, and of animal hunting, half was water hunting, and, taken as a whole, of water hunting the lower part was fishing, and of fishing, half was striking, and of striking, half was barb-hunting, and of this the part in which the blow is pulled from below upwards at an anglePlato's etymology—A)SPALIEUTIKH/ from A)NASPA=SQAI— is hardly less absurd than that suggested in the translation. The words at an angle are inserted merely to give a reason In English for the words which follow them. has a name in the very likeness of the act and is called angling, which was the object of our present search.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That at all events has been made perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come, then, let us use this as a pattern and try to find out what a sophist is.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, the first question we asked was whether we must assume that the angler was just a man or was a man with an art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now take this man of ours, Theaetetus. Shall we assume that he is just a man, or by all means really a man of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not just a man; for I catch your meaning that he is very far from being wise, although his name implies wisdom.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we must, it seems, assume that he has an art of some kind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, then, what in the world is this art that he has?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Good gracious! Have we failed to notice that the man is akin to the other man?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Who is akin to whom?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The angler to the sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They both seem clearly to me to be a sort of hunters.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is the hunting of the second? We have spoken about the first.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We just now divided hunting as a whole into two classes, and made one division that of swimming creatures and the other that of land-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the one we discussed, so far as the swimming creatures that live in the water are concerned; but we left the land-hunting undivided, merely remarking that it has many forms.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now up to that point the sophist and the angler proceed together from the starting-point of acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But they separate at the point of animal-hunting, where the one turns to the sea and rivers and lakes to hunt the animals in those.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the other turns toward the land and to rivers of a different kind—rivers of wealth and youth, bounteous meadows, as it were—and he intends to coerce the creatures in them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of land-hunting there are two chief divisions.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One is the hunting of tame, the other of wild creatures.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Is there, then, a hunting of tame creatures?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, If man is a tame animal; but make any assumption you like, that there is no tame animal, or that some other tame animal exists but man is a wild one or that man is tame but there is no hunting of man. For the purpose of our definition choose whichever of these statements you think is satisfactory to you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why, Stranger, I think we are a tame animal, and I agree that there is a hunting of man.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, say that the hunting of tame animals is also of two kinds.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How do we justify that assertion?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By defining piracy, man-stealing, tyranny, and the whole art of war all collectively as hunting by force.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And by giving the art of the law courts, of the public platform, and of conversation also a single name and calling them all collectively an art of persuasion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us say that there are two kinds of persuasion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What kinds?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one has to do with private persons, the other with the community.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Granted; each of them does form a class.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then again of the hunting of private persons one kind receives pay, and the other brings gifts, does it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Apparently you have never yet paid attention to the lovers' method of hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what respect?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That in addition to their other efforts they give presents to those whom they hunt.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, call this the amatory art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that part of the paid kind which converses to furnish gratification and makes pleasure exclusively its bait and demands as its pay only maintenance, we might all agree, if I am not mistaken, to call the art of flattery or of making things pleasant.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the class which proposes to carry on its conversations for the sake of virtue and demands its pay in cash—does not this deserve to be called by another name?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what is that name? Try to tell.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is obvious; for I think we have discovered the sophist. And therefore by uttering that word I think I should give him the right name.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, as it seems, according to our present reasoning, Theaetetus, the part of appropriative, coercive, hunting art which hunts animals, land animals, tame animals, man, privately, for pay, is paid in cash, claims to give education, and is a hunt after rich and promising youths, must—so our present argument concludes—be called sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Most assuredly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But let us look at it in still another way; for the class we are now examining partakes of no mean art, but of a very many-sided one. And we must indeed do so, for in our previous talk it presents an appearance of being, not what we now say it is, but another class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The acquisitive art was of two sorts, the one the division of hunting, the other that of exchange.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now shall we say that there are two sorts of exchange, the one by gift, the other by sale?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So be it.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall say further that exchange by sale is divided into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We make this distinction—calling the part which sells a man's own productions the selling of one's own, and the other, which exchanges the works of others, exchange.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, that part of exchange which is carried on in the city, amounting to about half of it, is called retailing, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that which exchanges goods from city to city by purchase and sale is called merchandising?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And have we not observed that one part of merchandising sells and exchanges for cash whatever serves the body for its support and needs, and the other whatever serves the soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps we do not know about the part that has to do with the soul; though I fancy we do understand the other division.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Take, therefore, the liberal artsThe word MOUSIKH/, here rendered “liberal arts,” is much more inclusive than the English word “music,” designating, as it does, nearly all education and culture except the purely physical. In the Athens of Socrates' day many, possibly most, of the teachers of music in this larger sense were foreigners, Greeks, of course, but not Athenians. in general that constantly go about from city to city, bought in one place and carried to another and sold—painting, and conjuring, and the many other things that affect the soul, which are imported and sold partly for its entertainment and partly for its serious needs; we cannot deny that he who carries these about and sells them constitutes a merchant properly so called, no less than he whose business is the sale of food and drink.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then will you give the same name to him who buys up knowledge and goes about from city to city exchanging his wares for money?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One part of this soul-merchandising might very properly be called the art of display, might it not? But since the other part, though no less ridiculous than the first, is nevertheless a traffic in knowledge, must we not call it by some name akin to its business?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now of this merchandising in knowledge the part which has to do with the knowledge of the other arts should be called by one name, and that which has to do with virtue by another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The name of art-merchant would fit the one who trades in the other arts, and now do you be so good as to tell the name of him who trades in virtue.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And what other name could one give, without making a mistake, than that which is the object of our present investigation—the sophist?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No other. Come then, let us now summarize the matter by saying that sophistry has appeared a second time as that part of acquisitive art, art of exchange, of trafficking, of merchandising, of soul-merchandising which deals in words and knowledge, and trades in virtue.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But there is a third case: If a man settled down here in town and proposed to make his living by selling these same wares of knowledge, buying some of them and making others himself, you would, I fancy, not call him by any other name than that which you used a moment ago.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then also that part of acquisitive art which proceeds by exchange, and by sale, whether as mere retail trade or the sale of one's own productions, no matter which, so long as it is of the class of merchandising in knowledge, you will always, apparently, call sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I must do so, for I have to follow where the argument leads.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us examine further and see if the class we are now pursuing has still another aspect, of similar nature.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of what nature?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We agreed that fighting was a division of acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is quite fitting to divide it into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell what the parts are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us call one part of it the competitive and the other the pugnacious.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is reasonable and fitting to give to that part of the pugnacious which consists of bodily contests some such name as violent.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what other name than controversy shall we give to the contests of words?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No other.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But controversy must be divided into two kinds.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whenever long speeches are opposed by long speeches on questions of justice and injustice in public, that is forensic controversy.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that which is carried on among private persons and is cut up into little bits by means of questions and their answers, we are accustomed to call argumentation, are we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that part of argumentation which deals with business contracts, in which there is controversy, to be sure, but it is carried on informally and without rules of art—all that must be considered a distinct class, now that our argument has recognized it as different from the rest, but it received no name from our predecessors, nor does it now deserve to receive one from us.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True; for the divisions into which it falls are too small and too miscellaneous.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that which possesses rules of art and carries on controversy about abstract justice and injustice and the rest in general terms, we are accustomed to call disputation, are we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, of disputation, one sort wastes money, the other makes money.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us try to tell the name by which we must call each of these.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we must do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Presumably the kind which causes a man to neglect his own affairs for the pleasure of engaging in it, but the style of which causes no pleasure to most of his hearers, is, in my opinion, called by no other name than garrulity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is about what it is called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the opposite of this, the kind which makes money from private disputes—try now, for it is your turn, to give its name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What other answer could one give without making a mistake, than that now again for the fourth time that wonderful being whom we have so long been pursuing has turned up—the sophist!

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and the sophist is nothing else, apparently, than the money-making class of the disputatious, argumentative, controversial, pugnacious, combative, acquisitive art, as our argument has now again stated.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see the truth of the statement that this creature is many-sided and, as the saying is, not to be caught with one hand?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Then we must catch him with both.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, we must, and must go at it with all our might, by following another track of his—in this way. Tell me; of the expressions connected with menial occupations some are in common use, are they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, many. But to which of the many does your question refer?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To such as these: we say “sift” and “strain” and “winnow” and “separate.”Apparently a term descriptive of some part of the process of weaving; cf. Plat. Crat. 338b.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And besides these there are “card” and “comb” and “beat the web” and countless other technical terms which we know. Is it not so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why do you use these as examples and ask about them all? What do you wish to show in regard to them?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: All those that I have mentioned imply a notion of division.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since there is, accorling to my reckoning, one art involved in all of these operations, let us give it one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What shall we call it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The art of discrimination.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now see if we can discover two divisions of this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You demand quick thinking, for a boy like me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet, in the instance of discrimination just mentioned there was, first, the separation of worse from better, and, secondly, of like from like.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, as you now express it, that is pretty clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now I know no common name for the second kind of discrimination; but I do know the name of the kind which retains the better and throws away the worse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Every such discrimination, as I think, is universally called a sort of purification.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And could not anyone see that purification is of two kinds?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, perhaps, in time; but still I do not see it now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Still there are many kinds of purifications of bodies, and they may all properly be included under one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they and what is the name?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The purification of living creatures, having to do with impurities within the body, such as are successfully discriminated by gymnastics and medicine, and with those outside of the body, not nice to speak of, such as are attended to by the bath-keeper's art; and the purification of inanimate bodies, which is the special care of the fuller's art and in general of the art of exterior decoration; this, with its petty subdivisions, has taken on many names which seem ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Certainly they do, Theaetetus. However, the method of argument is neither more nor less concerned with the art of medicine than with that of sponging, but is indifferent if the one benefits us little, the other greatly by its purifying. It endeavors to understand what is related and what is not related in all arts, for the purpose of acquiring intelligence; and therefore it honors them all equally and does not in making comparisons think one more ridiculous than another, and does not consider him who employs, as his example of hunting, the art of generalship, any more dignified than him who employs the art of louse-catching, but only, for the most part, as more pretentious. And now as to your question, what name we shall give to all the activities whose function it is to purify the body, whether animate or inanimate, it will not matter at all to our method what name sounds finest; it cares only to unite under one name all purifications of everything else and to keep them separate from the purification of the soul. For it has in our present discussion been trying to separate this purification definitely from the rest, if we understand its desire.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But I do understand and I agree that there are two kinds of purification and that one kind is the purification of the soul, which is separate from that of the body.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Most excellent. Now pay attention to the next point and try again to divide the term.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In whatever way you suggest, I will try to help you in making the division.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do we say that wickedness is distinct from virtue in the soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And purification was retaining the one and throwing out whatever is bad anywhere?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence whenever we find any removal of evil from the soul, we shall be speaking properly if we call that a purification.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very properly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must say that there are two kinds of evil in the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What kinds?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one is comparable to a disease in the body, the other to a deformity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps you have not considered that disease and discord are the same thing?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not know what reply I ought to make to this, either.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is that because you think discord is anything else than the disagreement of the naturally related, brought about by some corruption?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No; I think it is nothing else.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But is deformity anything else than the presence of the quality of disproportion, which is always ugly?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Nothing else at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then; do we not see that in the souls of worthless men opinions are opposed to desires, anger to pleasures, reason to pain, and all such things to one another?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they are, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yet they must all be naturally related.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we shall be right if we say that wickedness is a discord and disease of the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if things which partake of motion and aim at some particular mark pass beside the mark and miss it on every occasion when they try to hit it, shall we say that this happens to them through right proportion to one another or, on the contrary, through disproportion?The connection between disproportion and missing the mark is not obvious. The explanation that a missile (e.g. an arrow) which is not evenly balanced will not fly straight, fails to take account of the words PRO\S A)/LLHLA. The idea seems rather to be that moving objects of various sizes, shapes, and rates of speed must interfere with each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently through disproportion.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet we know that every soul, if ignorant of anything, is ignorant against its will.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now being ignorant is nothing else than the aberration of a soul that aims at truth, when the understanding passes beside the mark.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must regard a foolish soul as deformed and ill-proportioned.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there are, it appears, these two kinds of evils in the soul, one, which people call wickedness, which is very clearly a disease.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the other they call ignorance, but they are not willing to acknowledge that it is vice, when it arises only in the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It must certainly be admitted, though I disputed it when you said it just now, that there are two kinds of vice in the soul, and that cowardice, intemperance, and injustice must all alike be considered a disease in us, and the widespread and various condition of ignorance must be regarded as a deformity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In the case of the body there are two arts which have to do with these two evil conditions, are there not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For deformity there is gymnastics, and for disease medicine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence for insolence and injustice and cowardice is not the corrective art the one of all arts most closely related to Justice?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Probably it is, at least according to the judgement of mankind.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And for all sorts of ignorance is there any art it would be more correct to suggest than that of instruction?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, none.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come now, think. Shall we say that there is only one kind of instruction, or that there are more and that two are the most important?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I am thinking.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think we can find out most quickly in this way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By seeing whether ignorance admits of being cut in two in the middle; for if ignorance turns out to be twofold, it is clear that instruction must also consist of two parts, one for each part of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, can you see what you are now looking for?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I at any rate think I do see one large and grievous kind of ignorance, separate from the rest, and as weighty as all the other parts put together.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Thinking that one knows a thing when one does not know it. Through this, I believe, all the mistakes of the mind are caused in all of us.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And furthermore to this kind of ignorance alone the name of stupidity is given.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now what name is to be given to that part of instruction which gets rid of this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think, Stranger, that the other part is called instruction in handicraft, and that this part is here at Athens through our influence called education.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so it is, Theaetetus, among nearly all the Hellenes. But we must examine further and see whether it is one and indivisible or still admits of division important enough to have a name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we must see about that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think there is still a way in which this also may be divided.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: On what principle?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of instruction in arguments one method seems to be rougher, and the other section smoother.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What shall we call each of these?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The venerable method of our fathers, which they generally employed towards their sons, and which many still employ, of sometimes showing anger at their errors and sometimes more gently exhorting them—that would most properly be called as a whole admonition.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: On the other hand, some appear to have convinced themselves that all ignorance is involuntary, and that he who thinks himself wise would never be willing to learn any of those things in which he believes he is clever, and that the admonitory kind of education takes a deal of trouble and accomplishes little.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So they set themselves to cast out the conceit of cleverness in another way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They question a man about the things about which he thinks he is talking sense when he is talking nonsense; then they easily discover that his opinions are like those of men who wander, and in their discussions they collect those opinions and compare them with one another, and by the comparison they show that they contradict one another about the same things, in relation to the same things and in respect to the same things. But those who see this grow angry with themselves and gentle towards others, and this is the way in which they are freed from their high and obstinate opinions about themselves. The process of freeing them, moreover, affords the greatest pleasure to the listeners and the most lasting benefit to him who is subjected to it.
