For just as physicians who care for the body believe that the body cannot get benefit from any food offered to it until all obstructions are removed, so, my boy, those who purge the soul believe that the soul can receive no benefit from any teachings offered to it until someone by cross-questioning reduces him who is cross-questioned to an attitude of modesty, by removing the opinions that obstruct the teachings, and thus purges him and makes him think that he knows only what he knows, and no more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is surely the best and most reasonable state of mind.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For all these reasons, Theaetetus, we must assert that cross-questioning is the greatest and most efficacious of all purifications, and that he who is not cross-questioned, even though he be the Great King, has not been purified of the greatest taints, and is therefore uneducated and deformed in those things in which he who is to be truly happy ought to be most pure and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, who are those who practise this art? I am afraid to say the sophists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Lest we grant them too high a meed of honor.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But the description you have just given is very like someone of that sort.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and a wolf is very like a dog, the wildest like the tamest of animals. But the cautious man must be especially on his guard in the matter of resemblances, for they are very slippery things. However, let us agree that they are the sophists; for I think the strife will not be about petty discriminations when people are sufficiently on their guard.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, probably not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let it be agreed that part of the discriminating art is purification, and as part of purification let that which is concerned with the soul be separated off, and as part of this, instruction, and as part of instruction, education; and let us agree that the cross-questioning of empty conceit of wisdom, which has come to light in our present discussion, is nothing else than the true-born art of sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Let us agree to all that; but the sophist has by this time appeared to be so many things that I am at a loss to know what in the world to say he really is, with any assurance that I am speaking the truth.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No wonder you are at a loss. But it is fair to suppose that by this time he is still more at a loss to know how he can any longer elude our argument; for the proverb is right which says it is not easy to escape all the wrestler's grips. So now we must attack him with redoubled vigor.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: First, then, let us stop to take breath and while we are resting let us count up the number of forms in which the sophist has appeared to us. First, I believe, he was found to be a paid hunter after the young and wealthy.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And secondly a kind of merchant in articles of knowledge for the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And thirdly did he not turn up as a retailer of these same articles of knowledge?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, and fourthly we found he was a seller of his own productions of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Your memory is good; but I will try to recall the fifth case myself. He was an athlete in contests of words, who had taken for his own the art of disputation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The sixth case was doubtful, but nevertheless we agreed to consider him a purger of souls, who removes opinions that obstruct learning.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then do you see that when a man appears to know many things, but is called by the name of a single art, there is something wrong about this impression, and that, in fact, the person who labors under this impression in connexion with any art is clearly unable to see the common principle of the art, to which all these kinds of knowledge pertain, so that he calls him who possesses them by many names instead of one?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Something like that is very likely to be the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must not let that happen to us in our search through lack of diligence. So let us first take up again one of our statements about the sophist. For there is one of them which seemed to me to designate him most plainly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Which was it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think we said he was a disputer.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And did we not also say that he taught this same art of disputing to others?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us examine and see what the subjects are about which such men say they make their pupils able to dispute. Let us begin our examination at the beginning with this question: Is it about divine things which are invisible to others that they make people able to dispute?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is their reputation, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about the visible things of earth and heaven and the like?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Those are included, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And furthermore in private conversations, when the talk is about generation and being in general, we know (do we not?) that they are clever disputants themselves and impart equal ability to others.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about laws and public affairs in general? Do they not promise to make men able to argue about those?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, for nobody, to speak broadly, would attend their classes if they did not make that promise.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: However in all arts jointly and severally what the professional ought to answer to every opponent is written down somewhere and published that he who will may learn.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You seem to refer to the text-books of Protagoras on wrestling and the other arts.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, my friend, and to those of many other authors. But is not the art of disputation, in a word, a trained ability for arguing about all things?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, at any rate, it does not seem to leave much out.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For heaven's sake, my boy, do you think that is possible? For perhaps you young people may look at the matter with sharper vision than our duller sight.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean and just what do you refer to? I do not yet understand your question.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I ask whether it is possible for a man to know all things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: If that were possible, Stranger, ours would indeed be a blessed race.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How, then, can one who is himself ignorant say anything worth while in arguing with one who knows?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: He cannot at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what in the world can the magical power of the sophistical art be?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Magical power in what respect?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In the way in which they are able to make young men think that they themselves are in all matters the wisest of men. For it is clear that if they neither disputed correctly nor seemed to the young men to do so, or again if they did seem to dispute rightly but were not considered wiser on that account, nobody, to quote from you,Cf. Plat. Theaet. 232d. would care to pay them money to become their pupil in these subjects.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now people do care to do so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very much.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, for they are supposed, I fancy, to have knowledge themselves of the things about which they dispute.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And they do that about all things, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then they appear to their pupils to be wise in all things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Though they are not; for that was shown to be impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is a sort of knowledge based upon mere opinion that the sophist has been shown to possess about all things, not true knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly; and I shouldn't be surprised if that were the most accurate statement we have made about him so far.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us then take a clearer example to explain this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What sort of an example?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This one; and try to pay attention and to give a very careful answer to my question.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is the question?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If anyone should say that by virtue of a single art he knew how, not to assert or dispute, but to do and make all things—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by all things?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You fail to grasp the very beginning of what I said; for apparently you do not understand the word “all.”

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I mean you and me among the “all,” and the other animals besides, and the trees.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If one should say that he would make you and me and all other created beings.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What would he mean by “making”? Evidently you will not say that he means a husbandman; for you said he was a maker of animals also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and of sea and earth and heaven and gods and everything else besides; and, moreover, he makes them all quickly and sells them for very little.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: This is some joke of yours.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes? And when a man says that he knows all things and can teach them to another for a small price in a little time, must we not consider that a joke?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Surely we must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is there any more artistic or charming kind of joke than the imitative kind?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not; for it is of very frequent occurrence and, if I may say so, most diverse. Your expression is very comprehensive.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we recognize that he who professes to be able by virtue of a single art to make all things will be able by virtue of the painter's art, to make imitations which have the same names as the real things, and by showing the pictures at a distance will be able to deceive the duller ones among young children into the belief that he is perfectly able to accomplish in fact whatever he wishes to do.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, may we not expect to find that there is another art which has to do with words, by virtue of which it is possible to bewitch the young through their ears with words while they are still standing at a distance from the realities of truth, by exhibiting to them spoken images of all things, so as to make it seem that they are true and that the speaker is the wisest of all men in all things?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why should there not be such another art?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now most of the hearers, Theaetetus, when they have lived longer and grown older, will perforce come closer to realities and will be forced by sad experienceApparently a reference to a proverbial expression. Cf. Hes. WD 216 E)/GNW PAQW/N; Herodotus, 1.207 TA\ PAQH/MATA MAQH/MATA. openly to lay hold on realities; they will have to change the opinions which they had at first accepted, so that what was great will appear small and what was easy, difficult, and all the apparent truths in arguments will be turned topsy-turvy by the facts that have come upon them in real life. Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, at least so far as one of my age can judge. But I imagine I am one of those who are still standing at a distance.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore all of us elders here will try, and are now trying, to bring you as near as possible without the sad experience. So answer this question about the sophist: Is this now clear, that he is a kind of a juggler, an imitator of realities, or are we still uncertain whether he may not truly possess the knowledge of all the things about which he seems to be able to argue?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could that be, my dear sir? Surely it is pretty clear by this time from what has been said that he is one of those whose business is entertainment.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is to say, he must be classed as a juggler and imitator.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course he must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Look sharp, then; it is now our business not to let the beast get away again, for we have almost got him into a kind of encircling net of the devices we employ in arguments about such subjects, so that he will not now escape the next thing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What next thing?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The conclusion that he belongs to the class of conjurers.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I agree to that opinion of him, too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is decided, then, that we will as quickly as possible divide the image-making art and go down into it, and if the sophist stands his ground against us at first, we will seize him by the orders of reason, our king, then deliver him up to the king and display his capture. But if he tries to take cover in any of the various sections of the imitative art, we must follow him, always dividing the section into which he has retreated, until he is caught. For assuredly neither he nor any other creature will ever boast of having escaped from pursuers who are able to follow up the pursuit in detail and everywhere in this methodical way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right. That is what we must do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To return, then, to our previous method of division, I think I see this time also two classes of imitation, but I do not yet seem to be able to make out in which of them the form we are seeking is to be found.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Please first make the division and tell us what two classes you mean.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I see the likeness-making art as one part of imitation. This is met with, as a rule, whenever anyone produces the imitation by following the proportions of the original in length, breadth, and depth, and giving, besides, the appropriate colors to each part.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, but do not all imitators try to do this?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Not those who produce some large work of sculpture or painting. For if they reproduced the true proportions of beautiful forms, the upper parts, you know, would seem smaller and the lower parts larger than they ought, because we see the former from a distance, the latter from near at hand.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So the artists abandon the truth and give their figures not the actual proportions but those which seem to be beautiful, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That, then, which is other, but like, we may fairly call a likeness, may we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the part of imitation which is concerned with such things, is to be called, as we called it before, likeness-making?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is to be so called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now then, what shall we call that which appears, because it is seen from an unfavorable position, to be like the beautiful, but which would not even be likely to resemble that which it claims to be like, if a person were able to see such large works adequately? Shall we not call it, since it appears, but is not like, an appearance?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this is very common in painting and in all imitation?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And to the art which produces appearance, but not likeness, the most correct name we could give would be “fantastic art,” would it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: These, then, are the two forms of the image-making art that I meant, the likeness-making and the fantastic.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I was uncertain before in which of the two the sophist should be placed, and even now I cannot see clearly. The fellow is really wonderful and very difficult to keep in sight, for once more, in the very cleverest manner he has withdrawn into a baffling classification where it is hard to track him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you assent because you recognize the fact, or did the force of habit hurry you along to a speedy assent?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean, and why did you say that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We are really, my dear friend, engaged in a very difficult investigation; for the matter of appearing and seeming, but not being, and of saying things, but not true ones—all this is now and always has been very perplexing. You see, Theaetetus, it is extremely difficult to understand how a man is to say or think that falsehood really exists and in saying this not be involved in contradiction.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
Theaetetus
sp.p: Assume my consent to anything you wish. Consider only the argument, how it may best be pursued; follow your own course, and take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well, then. Now tell me; do we venture to use the phrase absolute not-being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If, then, not merely for the sake of discussion or as a joke, but seriously, one of his pupils were asked to consider and answer the question “To what is the designation 'not-being' to be applied?” how do we think he would reply to his questioner, and how would he apply the term, for what purpose, and to what object?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is a difficult question; I may say that for a fellow like me it is unanswerable.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But this is clear, anyhow, that the term “not-being” cannot be applied to any being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if not to being, then it could not properly be applied to something, either.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this is plain to us, that we always use the word “something” of some being, for to speak of “something” in the abstract, naked, as it were, and disconnected from all beings is impossible, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You assent because you recognize that he who says something must say some one thing?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And you will agree that “something” or “some” in the singular is the sign of one, in the dual of two, and in the plural of many.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And he who says not something, must quite necessarily say absolutely nothing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we cannot even concede that such a person speaks, but says nothing? We must even declare that he who undertakes to say “not-being” does not speak at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The argument could go no further in perplexity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Boast not too soon! For there still remains, my friend, the first and greatest of perplexities. It affects the very beginning of the matter.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Do not hesitate to speak.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To that which is may be added or attributed some other thing which is?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But shall we assert that to that which is not anything which is can be attributed?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we assume that all number is among the things which are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, if anything can be assumed to be.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us not even undertake to attribute either the singular or the plural of number to not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We should, apparently, not be right in undertaking that, as our argument shows.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How then could a man either utter in speech or even so much as conceive in his mind things which are not, or not-being, apart from number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell me how number is involved in such conceptions.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When we say “things which are not,” do we not attribute plurality to them?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in saying “a thing which is not,” do we not equally attribute the singular number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Obviously.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet we assert that it is neither right nor fair to undertake to attribute being to not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see, then, that it is impossible rightly to utter or to say or to think of not-being without any attribute, but it is a thing inconceivable, inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then was I mistaken just now in saying that the difficulty I was going to speak of was the greatest in our subject.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But is there a still greater one that we can mention?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Why, my dear fellow, don't you see, by the very arguments we have used, that not-being reduces him who would refute it to such difficulties that when he attempts to refute it he is forced to contradict himself?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Speak still more clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You must not look for more clearness in me; for although I maintained that not-being could have nothing to do with either the singular or the plural number, I spoke of it just now, and am still speaking of it, as one; for I say “that which is not.” You understand surely?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again a little while ago I said it was inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational. Do you follow me?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then when I undertook to attach the verb “to be” to not-being I was contradicting what I said before.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then; when I attached this verb to it, did I not address it in the singular?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And when I called it irrational, inexpressible, and unspeakable, I addressed my speech to it as singular.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course you did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we say that, if one is to speak correctly, one must not define it as either singular or plural, and must not even call it “it” at all; for even by this manner of referring to it one would be giving it the form of the singular.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But poor me, what can anyone say of me any longer? For you would find me now, as always before, defeated in the refutation of not-being. So, as I said before, we must not look to me for correctness of speech about not-being. But come now, let us look to you for it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come, I beg of you, make a sturdy effort, young man as you are, and try with might and main to say something correctly about not-being, without attributing to it either existence or unity or plurality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But I should be possessed of great and absurd eagerness for the attempt, if I were to undertake it with your experience before my eyes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, if you like, let us say no more of you and me; but until we find someone who can accomplish this, let us confess that the sophist has in most rascally fashion hidden himself in a place we cannot explore.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That seems to be decidedly the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so, if we say he has an art, as it were, of making appearances, he will easily take advantage of our poverty of terms to make a counter attack, twisting our words to the opposite meaning; when we call him an image-maker, he will ask us what we mean by “image,” exactly. So, Theaetetus, we must see what reply is to be made to the young man's question.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Obviously we shall reply that we mean the images in water and in mirrors, and those in paintings, too, and sculptures, and all the other things of the same sort.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is evident, Theaetetus, that you never saw a sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: He will make you think his eyes are shut or he has none at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When you give this answer, if you speak of something in mirrors or works of art, he will laugh at your words, when you talk to him as if he could see. He will feign ignorance of mirrors and water and of sight altogether, and will question you only about that which is deduced from your words.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which exists throughout all these things which you say are many but which you saw fit to call by one name, when you said “image” of them all, as if they were all one thing. So speak and defend yourself. Do not give way to the man at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why, Stranger, what can we say an image is, except another such thing fashioned in the likeness of the true one?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you mean another such true one, or in what sense did you say “such”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not a true one by any means, but only one like the true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And by the true you mean that which really is?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the not true is the opposite of the true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which is like, then, you say does not really exist, if you say it is not true.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But it does exist, in a way.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But not truly, you mean.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, except that it is really a likeness.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what we call a likeness, though not really existing, really does exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not-being does seem to have got into some such entanglement with being, and it is very absurd.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of course it is absurd. You see, at any rate, how by this interchange of words the many-headed sophist has once more forced us against our will to admit that not-being exists in a way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see that very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, how can we define his art without contradicting ourselves?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why do you say that? What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When, in talking about appearance, we say that he deceives and that his art is an art of deception, shall we say that our mind is misled by his art to hold a false opinion, or what shall we say?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We shall say that. What else could we say?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, again, false opinion will be that which thinks the opposite of reality, will it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You mean, then, that false opinion thinks things which are not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Does it think that things which are not, are not, or that things which are not at all, in some sense are?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It must think that things which are not in some sense are—that is, if anyone is ever to think falsely at all, even in a slight degree.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And does it not also think that things which certainly are, are not at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this too is falsehood?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is,

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And therefore a statement will likewise be considered false, if it declares that things which are, are not, or that things which are not, are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what other way could a statement be made false?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Virtually in no other way; but the sophist will not assent to this. Or how can any reasonable man assent to it, when the expressions we just agreed upon were previously agreed to be inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational, and inconceivable? Do we understand his meaning, Theaetetus?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course we understand that he will say we are contradicting our recent statements, since we dare to say that falsehood exists in opinions and words; for he will say that we are thus forced repeatedly to attribute being to not-being, although we agreed a while ago that nothing could be more impossible than that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You are quite right to remind me. But I think it is high time to consider what ought to be done about the sophist; for you see how easily and repeatedly he can raise objections and difficulties, if we conduct our search by putting him in the guild of false-workers and jugglers.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, we have gone through only a small part of them, and they are, if I may say so, infinite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It would, apparently, be impossible to catch the sophist, if that is the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, shall we weaken and give up the struggle now?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, I say; we must not do that, if we can in any way get the slightest hold of the fellow.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Will you then pardon me, and, as your words imply, be content if I somehow withdraw just for a short distance from this strong argument of his?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course I will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I have another still more urgent request to make of you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do not assume that I am becoming a sort of parricide.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In defending myself I shall have to test the theory of my father Parmenides, and contend forcibly that after a fashion not-being is and on the other hand in a sense being is not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is plain that some such contention is necessary.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, plain even to a blind man, as they say; for unless these statements are either disproved or accepted, no one who speaks about false words, or false opinion—whether images or likenesses or imitations or appearances—about the arts which have to do with them, can ever help being forced to contradict himself and make himself ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we must take courage and attack our father's theory here and now, or else, if any scruples prevent us from doing this, we must give the whole thing up.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But nothing in the world must prevent us.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then I have a third little request to make of you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You have only to utter it.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I said a while ago that I always have been too faint-hearted for the refutation of this theory, and so I am now.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so you did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am afraid that on account of what I have said you will think I am mad because I have at once reversed my position. You see it is for your sake that I am going to undertake the refutation, if I succeed in it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I certainly shall not think you are doing anything improper if you proceed to your refutation and proof; so go ahead boldly, so far as that is concerned.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, what would be a good beginning of a perilous argument? Ah, my boy, I believe the way we certainly must take is this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must first examine the points which now seem clear, lest we may have fallen into some confusion about them and may therefore carelessly agree with one another, thinking that we are judging correctly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Express your meaning more clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It seems to me that Parmenides and all who ever undertook a critical definition of the number and nature of realities have talked to us rather carelessly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Every one of them seems to tell us a story, as if we were children. One says there are three principles, that some of them are sometimes waging a sort of war with each other, and sometimes become friends and marry and have children and bring them up; and another says there are two, wet and dry or hot and cold, which he settles together and unites in marriage.This refers apparently to Pherecydes and the early lonians. And the Eleatic sect in our region, beginning with Xenophanes and even earlier, have their story that all things, as they are called, are really one. Then some IonianHeracleitus and his followers. and later some SicilianEmpedocles and his disciples. Muses reflected that it was safest to combine the two tales and to say that being is many and one, and is (or are) held together by enmity and friendship. For the more strenuous Muses say it is always simultaneously coming together and separating; but the gentler ones relaxed the strictness of the doctrine of perpetual strife; they say that the all is sometimes one and friendly, under the influence of Aphrodite, and sometimes many and at variance with itself by reason of some sort of strife. Now whether any of them spoke the truth in all this, or not, it is harsh and improper to impute to famous men of old such a great wrong as falsehood. But one assertion can be made without offence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That they paid too little attention and consideration to the mass of people like ourselves. For they go on to the end, each in his own way, without caring whether their arguments carry us along with them, or whether we are left behind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When one of them says in his talk that many, or one, or two are, or have become, or are becoming, and again speaks of hot mingling with cold, and in some other part of his discourse suggests separations and combinations, for heaven's sake, Theaetetus, do you ever understand what they mean by any of these things? I used to think, when I was younger, that I understood perfectly whenever anyone used this term “not-being,” which now perplexes us. But you see what a slough of perplexity we are in about it now.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And perhaps our minds are in this same condition as regards being also; we may think that it is plain sailing and that we understand when the word is used, though we are in difficulties about not-being, whereas really we understand equally little of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we may say the same of all the subjects about which we have been speaking.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We will consider most of them later, if you please, but now the greatest and foremost chief of them must be considered.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Or, obviously, do you mean that we must first investigate the term “being,” and see what those who use it think it signifies?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You have caught my meaning at once, Theaetetus. For I certainly do mean that this is the best method for us to use, by questioning them directly, as if they were present in person; so here goes: Come now, all you who say that hot and cold or any two such principles are the universe, what is this that you attribute to both of them when you say that both and each are? What are we to understand by this “being” (or “are”) of yours? Is this a third principle besides those two others, and shall we suppose that the universe is three, and not two any longer, according to your doctrine? For surely when you call one only of the two “being” you do not mean that both of them equally are; for in both cases“In both cases,” i.e. whether you say that one only is or that both are, they would both be one, namely being. they would pretty certainly be one and not two.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, do you wish to call both of them together being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, friends, we will say, even in that way you would very clearly be saying that the two are one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since we are in perplexity, do you tell us plainly what you wish to designate when you say “being.” For it is clear that you have known this all along, whereas we formerly thought we knew, but are now perplexed. So first give us this information, that we may not think we understand what you say, when the exact opposite is the case.— If we speak in this way and make this request of them and of all who say that the universe is more than one, shall we, my boy, be doing anything improper?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, must we not, so far as we can, try to learn from those who say that the universe is oneThe Eleatic Zeno and his school. what they mean when they say “being”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course we must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let them answer this question: Do you say that one only is? We do, they will say; will they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do you give the name of being to anything?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is it what you call “one,” using two names for the same thing, or how is this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is their next answer, Stranger?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is plain, Theaetetus, that he who maintains their theory will not find it the easiest thing in the world to reply to our present question or to any other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is rather ridiculous to assert that two names exist when you assert that nothing exists but unity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in general there would be no sense in accepting the statement that a name has any existence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because he who asserts that the name is other than the thing, says that there are two entities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, if he asserts that the name is the same as the thing, he will be obliged to say that it is the name of nothing, or if he says it is the name of something, the name will turn out to be the name of a name merely and of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the one will turn out to be the name of one and also the one of the name.In other words, “one,” considered as a word, will be the name of unity, but considered as a reality, it will be the unity of which the word “one” is the name. The sentence is made somewhat difficult of comprehension, doubtless for the purpose of indicating the confusion caused by the identification of the name wlth the thing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And will they say that the whole is other than the one which exists or the same with it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course they will and do say it is the same.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p:
If then the whole is, as Parmenides says,
On all sides like the mass of a well-rounded sphere, equally weighted in every direction from the middle; for neither greater nor less must needs be on this or that,Parmenides Fr. 8.43then being, being such as he describes it, has a center and extremes, and, having these, must certainly have parts, must it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet nothing hinders that which has parts from possessing the attribute of unity in all its parts and being in this way one, since it is all and whole.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But is it not impossible for that which is in this condition to be itself absolute unity?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Why surely that which is really one must, according to right reason, be affirmed to be absolutely without parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But such a unity consisting of many parts will not harmonize with reason.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we agree that being is one and a whole because it has the attribute of unity, or shall we deny that being is a whole at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is a hard choice that you offer me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is very true; for being, having in a way had unity imposed upon it, will evidently not be the same as unity, and the all will be more than one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, if being is not a whole through having had the attribute of unity imposed upon it, and the absolute whole exists, then it turns out that being lacks something of being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so, by this reasoning, since being is deprived of being, it will be not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again the all becomes more than the one, since being and the whole have acquired each its own nature.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if the whole does not exist at all, being is involved in the same difficulties as before, and besides not existing it could not even have ever come into existence

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which comes into existence always comes into existence as a whole. Therefore no one who does not reckon the whole among things that are can speak of existence or generation as being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That certainly seems to be true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And moreover, that which is not a whole cannot have any quantity at all; for if it has any quantity, whatever that quantity may be, it must necessarily be of that quantity as a whole.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so countless other problems, each one involving infinite difficulties, will confront him who says that being is, whether it be two or only one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The problems now in sight make that pretty clear; for each leads up to another which brings greater and more grievous wandering in connection with whatever has previously been said.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we have not discussed all those who treat accurately of being and not-beingThe Ionic philosophers, the Eleatics, Heracleitus, Empedocles, the Megarians, Gorgias, Protagoras, and Antisthenes all discussed the problem of being and not-being.; however, let this suffice. But we must turn our eyes to those whose doctrines are less precise, that we may know from all sources that it is no easier to define the nature of being than that of not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well, then, we must proceed towards those others also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And indeed there seems to be a battle like that of the gods and the giants going on among them, because of their disagreement about existence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Some of themThe atomists (Leucippus, Democritus, and their followers), who taught that nothing exists except atoms and the void. Possibly there is a covert reference to Aristippus who was, like Plato, a pupil of Socrates. drag down everything from heaven and the invisible to earth, actually grasping rocks and trees with their hands; for they lay their hands on all such things and maintain stoutly that that alone exists which can be touched and handled; for they define existence and body, or matter, as identical, and if anyone says that anything else, which has no body, exists, they despise him utterly, and will not listen to any other theory than their own.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Terrible men they are of whom you speak. I myself have met with many of them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore those who contend against them defend themselves very cautiously with weapons derived from the invisible world above, maintaining forcibly that real existence consists of certain ideas which are only conceived by the mind and have no body. But the bodies of their opponents, and that which is called by them truth, they break up into small fragments in their arguments, calling them, not existence, but a kind of generation combined with motion. There is always, Theaetetus, a tremendous battle being fought about these questions between the two parties.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, therefore, get from each party in turn a statement in defence of that which they regard as being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How shall we get it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is comparatively easy to get it from those who say that it consists in ideas, for they are peaceful folk; but from those who violently drag down everything into matter, it is more difficult, perhaps even almost impossible, to get it. However, this is the way I think we must deal with them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Our first duty would be to make them really better, if it were in any way possible; but if this cannot be done, let us pretend that they are better, by assuming that they would be willing to answer more in accordance with the rules of dialectic than they actually are. For the acknowledgement of anything by better men is more valid than if made by worse men. But it is not these men that we care about; we merely seek the truth.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now tell them, assuming that they have become better, to answer you, and do you interpret what they say.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let them tell whether they say there is such a thing as a mortal animal.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And they agree that this is a body with a soul in it, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Giving to soul a place among things which exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do they not say that one soul is just and another unjust, one wise and another foolish?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And do they not say that each soul becomes just by the possession and presence of justice, and the opposite by the possession and presence of the opposite?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they agree to this also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But surely they will say that that which is capable of becoming present or absent exists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they say that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Granting, then, that justice and wisdom and virtue in general and their opposites exist, and also, of course, the soul in which they become present, do they say that any of these is visible and tangible, or that they are all invisible?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That none of them is visible, or pretty nearly that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now here are some other questions. Do they say they possess any body?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They no longer answer the whole of that question in the same way. They say they believe the soul itself has a sort of body, but as to wisdom and the other several qualities about which you ask, they have not the face either to confess that they have no existence or to assert that they are all bodies.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is clear, Theaetetus, that our men have grown better; for the aboriginal sons of the dragon's teethThis refers to the story of Cadmus, who killed a dragon and then sowed its teeth, from which sprang fierce warriors to be his companions. Born of the dragon's teeth and of earth, they would naturally be of the earth, earthy. among them would not shrink from any such utterance; they would maintain that nothing which they cannot squeeze with their hands has any existence at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is pretty nearly what they believe.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us question them further; for if they are willing to admit that any existence, no matter how small, is incorporeal, that is enough. They will then have to tell what is which is inherent in the incorporeal and the corporeal alike, and which they have in mind when they say that both exit. Perhaps they would be at a loss for an answer; and if they are in that condition, consider whether they might not accept a suggestion if we offered it, and might not agree that the nature of being is as follows.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it? Speak, and we shall soon know.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I suggest that everything which possesses any power of any kind, eithr to produce a change in anything of any nature or to be affected even in the least degree by the slightest cause, though it be only on one occasion, has real existence. For I set up as a definition which defines being, that it is nothing else but power.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, since they have at the moment nothing better of their own to offer, they accept this.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Good; for perhaps later something else may occur to them and to us. As between them and us, then, let us asume that this is for the present agreed upon and settled.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is settled.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us go to the others, the friends of ideas; and do you interpret for us their doctrines also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You distinguish in your speech between generation and being, do you not?i.e., between the process of coming into existence and existence itself. It is difficult to determine exactly who the idealists are whose doctrines are here discussed. Possibly Plato is restating or amending some of his own earlier beliefs.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And you say that with the body, by means of perception, we participate in generation, and with the soul, by means of thought, we participate in real being, which last is always unchanged and the same, whereas generation is different at different times.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is what we say.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, most excellent men, how shall we define this participation which you attribute to both? Is it not that of which we were just speaking?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: A passive or active condition arising out of some power which is derived from a combination of elements. Possibly, Theaetetus, you do not hear their reply to this, but I hear it, perhaps, because I am used to them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it, then, that they say?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They do not concede to us what we said just now to the aboriginal giants about being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We set up as a satisfactory sort of definition of being, the presence of the power to act or be acted upon in even the slightest degree.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is in reply to this that they say generation participates in the power of acting and of being acted upon, but that neither power is connected with being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And is there not something in that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, something to which we must reply that we still need to learn more clearly from them whether they agree that the soul knows and that being is known.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They certainly assent to that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do you say that knowing or being known is an active or passive condition, or both? Or that one is passive and the other active? Or that neither has any share at all in either of the two?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Clearly they would say that neither has any share in either; for otherwise they would be contradicting themselves.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I understand; this at least is true, that if to know is active, to be known must in turn be passive. Now being, since it is, according to this theory, known by the intelligence, in so far as it is known, is moved, since it is acted upon, which we say cannot be the case with that which is in a state of rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But for heaven's sake, shall we let ourselves easily be persuaded that motion and life and soul and mind are really not present to absolute being, that it neither lives nor thinks, but awful and holy, devoid of mind, is fixed and immovable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That would be a shocking admission to make, Stranger.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But shall we say that it has mind, but not life?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How can we?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But do we say that both of these exist in it, and yet go on to say that it does not possess them in a soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But how else can it possess them?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we say that it has mind and life and soul, but, although endowed with soul, is absolutely immovable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: All those things seem to me absurd.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it must be conceded that motion and that which is moved exist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the result is, Theaetetus, that if there is no motion, there is no mind in anyone about anything anywhere.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And on the other hand, if we admit that all things are in flux and motion, we shall remove mind itself from the number of existing things by this theory also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you think that sameness of quality or nature or relations could ever come into existence without the state of rest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What then? Without these can you see how mind could exist or come into existence anywhere?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet we certainly must contend by every argument against him who does away with knowledge or reason or mind and then makes any dogmatic assertion about anything.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the philosopher, who pays the highest honor to these things, must necessarily, as it seems, because of them refuse to accept the theory of those who say the universe is at rest, whether as a unity or in many forms, and must also refuse utterly to listen to those who say that being is universal motion; he must quote the children's prayer,Nothing further seems to he known about this prayer. Stallbaum thought the reference was to a game in which the children said O(/SA A)KI/NHTA KAI\ KEKINHME/NA EI)/H, “may all unmoved things be moved.” “all things immovable and in motion,” and must say that being and the universe consist of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do we not, then, seem to have attained at last a pretty good definition of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But dear me, Theaetetus! I think we are now going to discover the difficulty of the inquiry about being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is this again? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: My dear fellow, don't you see that we are now densely ignorant about it, but think that we are saying something worth while?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think so, at any rate, and I do not at all understand what hidden error we have fallen into.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then watch more closely and see whether, if we make these admissions, we may not justly be asked the same questions we asked a while ago of those who said the universe was hot and cold.Cf. 242d above.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What questions? Remind me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Certainly; and I will try to do this by questioning you, as we questioned them at the time. I hope we shall at the same time make a little progress.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well, then; you say that motion and rest are most directly opposed to each other, do you not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet you say that both and each of them equally exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in granting that they exist, do you mean to say that both and each are in motion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But do you mean that they are at rest, when you say that both exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Being, then, you consider to be something else in the soul, a third in addition to these two, inasmuch as you think rest and motion are embraced by it; and since you comprehend and observe that they participate in existence, you therefore said that they are. Eh?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We really do seem to have a vague vision of being as some third thing, when we say that motion and rest are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then being is not motion and rest in combination, but something else, different from them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: According to its own nature, then, being is neither at rest nor in motion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are about right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What is there left, then, to which a man can still turn his mind who wishes to establish within himself any clear conception of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What indeed?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: There is nothing left, I think, to which he can turn easily. For if a thing is not in motion, it must surely be at rest; and again, what is not at rest, must surely be in motion. But now we find that being has emerged outside of both these classes. Is that possible, then?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, nothing could be more impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there is this further thing which we ought to remember.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That when we were asked to what the appellation of not-being should be applied, we were in the greatest perplexity. Do you remember?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course I do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, are we now in any less perplexity about being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It seems to me, stranger, that we are, if possible, in even greater.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This point, then, let us put down definitely as one of complete perplexity. But since being and not-being participate equally in the perplexity, there is now at last some hope that as either of them emerges more dimly or more clearly, so also will the other emerge. If, however, we are able to see neither of them, we will at any rate push our discussion through between both of them at once as creditably as we can.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, explain how we come to be constantly calling this same thing by many names.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What, for instance? Please give an example.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We speak of man, you know, and give him many additional designations; we attribute to him colors and forms and sizes and vices and virtues, and in all these cases and countless others we say not only that he is man, but we say he is good and numberless other things. So in the same way every single thing which we supposed to be one, we treat as many and call by many names.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it is in this way, I fancy, that we have provided a fine feast for youngsters and for old men whose learning has come to them late in life; for example, it is easy enough for anyone to grasp the notion that the many cannot possibly be one, nor the one many, and so, apparently, they take pleasure in saying that we must not call a man good, but must call the good good, and a man man. I fancy, Theaetetus, you often run across people who take such matters seriously; sometimes they are elderly men whose poverty of intellect makes them admire such quibbles, and who think this is a perfect mine of wisdom they have discovered.Those are here satirized who deny the possibillty of all except identical predication. Such were Antisthenes, Euthydemus, and Dionysodorus. The two last are probably those referred to as old men whose learning came late in life.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, to include in our discussion all those who have ever engaged in any talk whatsoever about being, let us address our present arguments to these men as well as to all those with whom we were conversing before, and let us employ the form of questions.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are the arguments?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we attribute neither being to rest and motion, nor any attribute to anything, but shall we in our discussions assume that they do not mingle and cannot participate in one another? Or shall we gather all things together, believing that they are capable of combining with one another? Or are some capable of it and others not? Which of these alternatives, Theaetetus, should we say is their choice?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I cannot answer these questions for them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then why did you not answer each separately and see what the result was in each case?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: A good suggestion.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And let us, if you please, assume that they say first that nothing has any power to combine with anything else. Then motion and rest will have no share in being, will they?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, will either of them be, if it has no share in being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: See how by this admission everything is overturned at once, as it seems—the doctrine of those who advocate universal motion, that of the partisans of unity and rest, and that of the men who teach that all existing things are distributed into invariable and everlasting kinds. For all of these make use of being as an attribute. One party says that the universe “is” in motion, another that it “is” at rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, all who teach that things combine at one time and separate at another, whether infinite elements combine in unity and are derived from unity or finite elements separate and then unite, regardless of whether they say that these changes take place successively or without interruption, would be talking nonsense in all these doctrines, if there is no intermingling.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, too, the very men who forbid us to call anything by another name because it participates in the effect produced by another, would be made most especially ridiculous by this doctrine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because they are obliged in speaking of anything to use the expressions “to be,” “apart,” “from the rest,” “by itself,” and countless others; they are powerless to keep away from them or avoid working them into their discourse; and therefore there is no need of others to refute them, but, as the saying goes, their enemy and future opponent is of their own household whom they always carry about with them as they go, giving forth speech from within them, like the wonderful Eurycles.Eurycles was a ventriloquist and soothsayer of the fifth century, cf. Aristoph. Wasps 1019

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is a remarkably accurate illustration

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what if we ascribe to all things the power of participation in one another?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Even I can dispose of that assumption.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Because motion itself would be wholly at rest, and rest in turn would itself be in motion, if these two could be joined with one another.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But surely this at least is most absolutely impossible, that motion be at rest and rest be in motion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then only the third possibility is left.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And certainly one of these three must be true; either all things will mingle with one another, or none will do so, or some will and others will not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And certainly the first two were found to be impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then everybody who wishes to answer correctly will adopt the remaining one of the three possibilities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now since some things will commingle and others will not, they are in much the same condition as the letters of the alphabet; for some of these do not fit each other, and others do.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the vowels, to a greater degree than the others, run through them all as a bond, so that without one of the vowels the other letters cannot be joined one to another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now does everybody know which letters can join with which others? Or does he who is to join them properly have need of art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: He has need of art.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The art of grammar.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is not the same true in connection with high and low sounds? Is not he who has the art to know the sounds which mingle and those which do not, musical, and he who does not know unmusical?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall find similar conditions, then, in all the other arts and processes which are devoid of art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now since we have agreed that the classes or genera also commingle with one another, or do not commingle, in the same way, must not he possess some science and proceed by the processes of reason who is to show correctly which of the classes harmonize with which, and which reject one another, and also if he is to show whether there are some elements extending through all and holding them together so that they can mingle, and again, when they separate, whether there are other universal causes of separation?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly he needs science, and perhaps even the greatest of sciences.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, Theaetetus, what name shall we give to this science? Or, by Zeus, have we unwittingly stumbled upon the science that belongs to free men and perhaps found the philosopher while we were looking for the sophist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we not say that the division of things by classes and the avoidance of the belief that the same class is another, or another the same, belongs to the science of dialectic?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we shall.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then he who is able to do this has a clear perception of one form or idea extending entirely through many individuals each of which lies apart, and of many forms differing from one another but included in one greater form, and again of one form evolved by the union of many wholes, and of many forms entirely apart and separate. This is the knowledge and ability to distinguish by classes how individual things can or cannot be associated with one another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But you surely, I suppose, will not grant the art of dialectic to any but the man who pursues philosophy in purity and righteousness.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could it be granted to anyone else?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is in some region like this that we shall always, both now and hereafter, discover the philosopher, if we look for him; he also is hard to see clearly, but the difficulty is not the same in his case and that of the sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How do they differ?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The sophist runs away into the darkness of not-being, feeling his way in it by practice,By practice, i.e., by empirical knowledge as opposed to reason. and is hard to discern on account of the darkness of the place. Don't you think so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It seems likely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the philosopher, always devoting himself through reason to the idea of being, is also very difficult to see on account of the brilliant light of the place; for the eyes of the soul of the multitude are not strong enough to endure the sight of the divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: This also seems no less true than what you said about the sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we will make more accurate investigations about the philosopher hereafter, if we still care to do so; but as to the sophist, it is clear that we must not relax our efforts until we have a satisfactory view of him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Since, therefore, we are agreed that some of the classes will mingle with one another, and others will not, and some will mingle with few and others with many, and that there is nothing to hinder some from mingling universally with all, let us next proceed with our discussion by investigating, not all the forms or ideas, lest we become confused among so many, but some only, selecting them from those that are considered the most important; let us first consider their several natures, then what their power of mingling with one another is, and so, if we cannot grasp being and not-being with perfect clearness, we shall at any rate not fail to reason fully about them, so far as the method of our present inquiry permits. Let us in this way see whether it is, after all, permitted us to say that not-being really is, although not being, and yet come off unscathed.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes; that is the proper thing for us to do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The most important, surely, of the classes or genera are those which we just mentioned; being itself and rest and motion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, by far.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, two of them, we say, cannot mingle with each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Decidedly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But being can mingle with both of them, for they both are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then these prove to be three.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Each of them is, then, other than the remaining two, but the same as itself.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what do we mean by these words, “the same” and “other,” which we have just used? Are they two new classes, different from the other three, but always of necessity mingled with them, and must we conduct our inquiry on the assumption that there are five classes, not three, or are we unconsciously speaking of one of those three when we say “the same” or “other”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But certainly motion and rest are neither other nor the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whatever term we apply to rest and motion in common cannot be either of those two.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because motion would be at rest and rest would be in motion; in respect of both, for whichever of the two became “other” would force the other to change its nature into that of its opposite, since it would participate in its opposite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Both certainly partake of the same and the other.i.e., sameness and difference can he predicated of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must not say that motion, or rest either, is the same or other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But should we conceive of “being” and “the same” as one?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if “being” and “the same” have no difference of meaning, then when we go on and say that both rest and motion are, we shall be saying that they are both the same, since they are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But surely that is impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is impossible for being and the same to be one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Pretty nearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So we shall consider “the same” a fourth class in addition to the other three?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we call “the other” a fifth class? Or must we conceive of this and “being” as two names for one class?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: May be.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I fancy you admit that among the entities some are always conceived as absolute, and some as relative.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And other is always relative to other, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It would not be so, if being and the other were not utterly different. If the other, like being, partook of both absolute and relative existence, there would be also among the others that exist another not in relation to any other; but as it is, we find that whatever is other is just what it is through compulsion of some other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The facts are as you say.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must place the nature of “the other” as a fifth among the classes in which we select our examples.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall say that it permeates them all; for each of them is other than the rest, not by reason of its own nature, but because it partakes of the idea of the other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us now state our conclusions, taking up the five classes one at a time.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Take motion first; we say that it is entirely other than rest, do we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is not rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it exists, by reason of its participation in being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it exists.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now motion again is other than the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You're about right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore it is not the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, it is not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet we found it was the same, because all things partake of the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must admit that motion is the same and is not the same, and we must not be disturbed thereby; for when we say it is the same and not the same, we do not use the words alike. When we call it the same, we do so because it partakes of the same in relation to itself, and when we call it not the same, we do so on account of its participation in the other, by which it is separated from the same and becomes not that but other, so that it is correctly spoken of in turn as not the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then even if absolute motion partook in any way of rest, it would not be absurd to say it was at rest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It would be perfectly right, if we are to admit that some of the classes will mingle with one another, and others will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely we demonstrated that before we took up our present points; we proved that it was according to nature.See Plat. Theaet. 251e ff

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us recapitulate: Motion is other than the other, just as we found it to be other than the same and than rest. Is that true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Inevitably.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is in a sense not other and also other, according to our present reasoning.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now how about the next point? Shall we say next that motion is other than the three, but not other than the fourth,—that is, if we have agreed that the classes about which and within which we undertook to carry on our inquiry are five in number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How can we say that? For we cannot admit that the number is less than was shown just now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we may fearlessly persist in contending that motion is other than being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, most fearlessly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is clear, then, that motion really is not, and also that it is, since it partakes of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In relation to motion, then, not-being is. That is inevitable. And this extends to all the classes; for in all of them the nature of other so operates as to make each one other than being, and therefore not-being. So we may, from this point of view, rightly say of all of them alike that they are not; and again, since they partake of being, that they are and have being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
