sp.p: And so, in relation to each of the classes, being is many, and not-being is infinite in number.Being is many, for each and every thing in all the classes is; but not-being is infinite, for not only is it true that everything in each of the classes is not, but not-being extends also to all conceptions which do not and cannot have any reality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then being itself must also be said to be other than all other things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we conclude that whatever the number of other things is, just that is the number of the things in relation to which being is not; for not being those things, it is itself one, and again, those other things are not unlimited in number.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is not far from the truth.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must not be disturbed by this either, since by their nature the classes have participation in one another. But if anyone refuses to accept our present results, let him reckon with our previous arguments and then proceed to reckon with the next step.i.e., if he will not accept our proof that being is not, etc., he must disprove our arguuents respecting the participation of idea in one another, and then proceed to draw his inference.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is very fair.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then here is a point to consider.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When we say not-being, we speak, I think, not of something that is the opposite of being, but only of something different.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For instance, when we speak of a thing as not great, do we seem to you to mean by the expression what is small any more than what is of middle size?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then when we are told that the negative signifies the opposite, we shall not admit it; we shall admit only that the particle “not”The two particles OU) and MH/ in Greek. indicates something different from the words to which it is prefixed, or rather from the things denoted by the words that follow the negative.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us consider another point and see if you agree with me.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It seems to me that the nature of the other is all cut up into little bits, like knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Knowledge, like other, is one, but each separate part of it which applies to some particular subject has a name of its own; hence there are many arts, as they are called, and kinds of knowledge, or sciences.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the same is true, by their nature, of the parts of the other, though it also is one concept.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps; but let us discuss the matter and see how it comes about.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is there a part of the other which is opposed to the beautiful?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we say that this is nameless or that it has a name?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That it has one; for that which in each case we call not-beautiful is surely the other of the nature of the beautiful and of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, tell me something more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Does it not result from this that the not-beautiful is a distinct part of some one class of being and also, again, opposed to some class of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, apparently, it follows that the not-beautiful is a contrast of being with being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Can we, then, in that case, say that the beautiful is more and the not-beautiful less a part of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence the not-great must be said to be no less truly than the great?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No less truly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we must recognize the same relation between the just and the not-just, in so far as neither has any more being than the other?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall, then, say the same of other things, since the nature of the other is proved to possess real being; and if it has being, we must necessarily ascribe being in no less degree to its parts also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, as it seems, the opposition of the nature of a part of the other, and of the nature of being, when they are opposed to one another, is no less truly existence than is being itself, if it is not wrong for me to say so, for it signifies not the opposite of being, but only the other of being, and nothing more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what shall we call this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently this is precisely not-being, which we were looking for because of the sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is this, as you were saying, as fully endowed with being as anything else, and shall we henceforth say with confidence that not-being has an assured existence and a nature of its own? Just as we found that the great was great and the beautiful was beautiful, the not-great was not-great and the not-beautiful was not-beautiful, shall we in the same way say that not-being was and is not-being, to be counted as one class among the many classes of being? Or have we, Theaetetus, any remaining distrust about the matter?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: None whatever.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you observe, then, that we have gone farther in our distrust of Parmenides than the limit set by his prohibition?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We have proceeded farther in our investigation and have shown him more than that which he forbade us to examine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is what he says.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we have not only pointed out that things which are not exist, but we have even shown what the form or class of not-being is; for we have pointed out that the nature of the other exists and is distributed in small bits throughout all existing things in their relations to one another, and we have ventured to say that each part of the other which is contrasted with being, really is exactly not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And certainly, Stranger, I think that what we have said is perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let not anyone assert that we declare that not-being is the opposite of being, and hence are so rash as to say that not-being exists. For we long ago gave up speaking of any opposite of being, whether it exists or not and is capable or totally incapable of definition. But as for our present definition of not-being, a man must either refute us and show that we are wrong, or, so long as he cannot do that, he too must say, as we do, that the classes mingle with one another, and being and the other permeate all things, including each other, and the other, since it participates in being, is, by reason of this participation, yet is not that in which it participates, but other, and since it is other than being, must inevitably be not-being. But being, in turn, participates in the other and is therefore other than the rest of the classes, and since it is other than all of them, it is not each one of them or all the rest, but only itself; there is therefore no doubt that there are thousands and thousands of things which being is not, and just so all other things, both individually and collectively, in many relations are, and in many are not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if any man has doubts about these oppositions, he must make investigations and advance better doctrines than these of ours; or if he finds pleasure in dragging words about and applying them to different things at different times, with the notion that he has invented something difficult to explain, our present argument asserts that he has taken up seriously matters which are not worth serious attention; for this process is neither clever nor difficult, whereas here now is something both difficult and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What I have spoken of before—the ability to let those quibbles go as of no account and to follow and refute in detail the arguments of a man who says that other is in a sense the same, or that the same is other, and to do this from that point of view and with regard for those relations which he presupposes for either of these conditions. But to show that in some sort of fashion the same is the other, and the other the same, and the great small, and the like unlike, and to take pleasure in thus always bringing forward opposites in the argument,—all that is no true refutation, but is plainly the newborn offspring of some brain that has just begun to lay hold upon the problem of realities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For certainly, my friend, the attempt to separate everything from everything else is not only not in good taste but also shows that a man is utterly uncultivated and unphilosophical.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The complete separation of each thing from all is the utterly final obliteration of all discourse. For our power of discourse is derived from the interweaving of the classes or ideas with one another.The denial, that is to say, of all the interrelations of ideas leads to purely negative results. Examples of this are the exclusive antithesis of being and not-being and the mutual exclusion of rest and motion. The difficulty is solved at once when we recognize that positive and negative are necessarily interwoven in the nature of things, that the negative has only a relative existence and is not the opposite of the positive, but only different from it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Observe, then, that we have now been just in time in carrying our point against the supporters of such doctrine, and in forcing them to admit that one thing mingles with another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What was our object?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Our object was to establish discourse as one of our classes of being. For if we were deprived of this, we should be deprived of philosophy, which would be the greatest calamity; moreover, we must at the present moment come to an agreement about the nature of discourse, and if we were robbed of it by its absolute non-existence, we could no longer discourse; and we should be robbed of it if we agreed that there is no mixture of anything with anything.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is true enough; but I do not understand why we must come to an agreement about discourse just now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps the easiest way for you to understand is by following this line of argument.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What line?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We found that not-being was one of the classes of being, permeating all being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So the next thing is to inquire whether it mingles with opinion and speech.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If it does not mingle with them, the necessary result is that all things are true, but if it does, then false opinion and false discourse come into being; for to think or say what is not—that is, I suppose, falsehood arising in mind or in words.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if falsehood exists, deceit exists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if deceit exists, all things must be henceforth full of images and likenesses and fancies.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we said that the sophist had taken refuge in this region and had absolutely denied the existence of falsehood: for he said that not-being could be neither conceived nor uttered, since not-being did not in any way participate in being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now not-being has been found to partake of being, and so, perhaps, he would no longer keep up the fight in this direction; but he might say that some ideas partake of not-being and some do not, and that speech and opinion are among those which do not; and he would therefore again contend that the image-making and fantastic art, in which we placed him, has absolutely no existence, since opinion and speech have no participation in not-being; for falsehood cannot possibly exist unless such participation takes place. For this reason we must first inquire into the nature of speech and opinion and fancy,The English word “fancy,” though etymologically identical with the Greek FANTASI/A, has lost the close connection with “seeming” (FAI/NESQAI) which the Greek retains. The Greek word is therefore more comprehensive than the English, denoting that which appears to be, whether as the result of imagination or of sensation. Cf. 235 D ff. in order that when they are made clear we may perceive that they participate in not-being, and when we have perceived that, may prove the existence of falsehood, and after proving that, may imprison the sophist therein, if he can be held on that charge, and if not, may set him free and seek him in another class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It certainly seems, Stranger, that what you said at first about the sophist—that he was a hard kind of creature to catch—is true; for he seems to have no end of defences,Perhaps a sort of pun is intended, for PRO/BLHMA was already beginning to have the meaning of “problem.” and when he throws one of them up, his opponent has first to fight through it before he can reach the man himself; for now, you see, we have barely passed through the non-existence of being, which was his first prepared line of defence, when we find another line ready; and so we must prove that falsehood exists in relation to opinion and to speech; and after this, perhaps, there will be another line, and still another after that; and it seems no end will ever appear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No one should be discouraged, Theaetetus, who can make constant progress, even though it be slow. For if a man is discouraged under these conditions, what would he do under others—if he did not get ahead at all or were even pressed back? It would be a long time, as the saying is, before such a man would ever take a city. But now, my friend, since we have passed the line you speak of, the main defences would surely be in our hands, and the rest will now be smaller and easier to take.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: First, then, let us take up speech and opinion, as I said just now, in order to come to a clearer understanding whether not-being touches them, or they are both entirely true, and neither is ever false.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us now investigate names, just a we spoke a while ago about ideas and letters; for in that direction the object of our present search is coming in sight.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do we need to understand about names?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whether they all unite with one another, or none of them, or some will and some will not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently the last; some will and some will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This, perhaps, is what you mean, that those which are spoken in order and mean something do unite, but those that mean nothing in their sequence do not unite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so, and what do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What I supposed you had in mind when you assented; for we have two kinds of vocal indications of being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One called nouns, the other verbs.The science of language, in all its branches, was young in the time of Plato. Words of general meaning were necessarily used in a technical sense. So here O)/NOMA and R(H=MA are used as parts of grammatical terminology in the sense of “verb” and “noun,” though Plato elsewhere employs them with their ordinary meanings. Similarly the distinction between vowels and consonants (Plat. Theaet. 203; cf. Plat. Soph. 253) was at least relatively new, as was that between the active and the passive voice. How important Plato's part was in the development of linguistic study can no longer be accurately determined.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Define each of them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The indication which relates to action we may call a verb.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the vocal sign applied to those who perform the actions in question we call a noun.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence discourse is never composed of nouns alone spoken in succession, nor of verbs spoken without nouns.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I see; you evidently had something else in mind when you assented just now; for what I wished to say was just this, that verbs and nouns do not make discourse if spoken successively in this way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For instance, “walks,” “runs,” “sleeps” and the other verbs which denote actions, even if you utter all there are of them in succession, do not make discourse for all that.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again, when “lion,” “stag,” “horse,” and all other names of those who perform these actions are uttered, such a succession of words does not yet make discourse; for in neither case do the words uttered indicate action or inaction or existence of anything that exists or does not exist, until the verbs are mingled with the nouns; then the words fit, and their first combination is a sentence, about the first and shortest form of discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When one says “a man learns,” you agree that this is the least and first of sentences, do you not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For when he says that, he makes a statement about that which is or is becoming or has become or is to be; he does not merely give names, but he reaches a conclusion by combining verbs with nouns. That is why we said that he discourses and does not merely give names, and therefore we gave to this combination the name of discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That was right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So, then, just as of things some fit each other and some do not, so too some vocal signs do not fit, but some of them do fit and form discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now there is another little point.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: A sentence, if it is to be a sentence, must have a subject; without a subject it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it must also be of some quality, must it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us pay attention to each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, at any rate we ought to do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, I will speak a sentence to you in which a action and the result of action are combined by means of a noun and a verb, and whatever the subject of the sentence is do you tell me.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will, to the best of my ability.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: “Theaetetus sits.” It isn't a long sentence, is it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, it is fairly short.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now it is for you to say what it is about and what its subject is.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Clearly it is about me, and I am its subject.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about this sentence?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What one?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: “Theaetetus, with whom I am now talking, flies.”

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Every one would agree that this also is about me and I am its subject.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we agree that every sentence must have some quality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now what quality shall be ascribed to each of these sentences?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: One is false, I suppose, the other true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The true one states facts as they are about you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the false one states things that are other than the facts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In other words, it speaks of things that are not as if they were.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is pretty much what it does.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And states with reference to you that things are which are other than things which actually are; for we said, you know, that in respect to everything there are many things that are and many that are not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now the second of my sentences about you is in the first place by sheer necessity one of the shortest which conform to our definition of sentence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: At any rate we just now agreed on that point.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And secondly it has a subject.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if you are not the subject, there is none.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if there is no subject, it would not be a sentence at all; for we showed that a sentence without a subject is impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now when things are said about you, but things other are said as the same and things that are not as things that are, it appears that when such a combination is formed of verbs and nouns we have really and truly false discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, very truly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is it, then, not already plain that the three classes, thought, opinion, and fancy, all arise in our minds as both false and true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How is it plain?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You will understand more easily if you first grap their natures and the several differences between them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Give me an opportunity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, thought and speech are the same; only the former, which is a silent inner conversation of the soul with itself, has been given the special name of thought. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the stream that flows from the soul in vocal utterance through the mouth has the name of speech?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in speech we know there is just—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Affirmation and negation

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we know that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now when this arises in the soul silently by way of thought, can you give it any other name than opinion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And when such a condition is brought about in anyone, not independently, but through sensation, can it properly be called anything but seeming, or fancy?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since speech, as we found, is true and false, and we saw that thought is conversation of the soul with itself, and opinion is the final result of thought, and what we mean when we say “it seems” is a mixture of sensation and opinion, it is inevitable that, since these are all akin to speech, some of them must sometimes be false.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see, then, that false opinion and false discourse were found sooner than we expected when we feared a few moments ago that in looking for them we were undertaking an endless task?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us not be discouraged about the rest of our search, either; for now that these points are settled, we have only to revert to our previous divisions into classes.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What divisions?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We made two classes of image-making, the likeness-making and the fantastic.See Plat. Theaet. 235d ff

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we said that we did not know to which of the two the sophist should be assigned.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in the midst of our perplexity about that, we were overwhelmed by a still greater dizziness when the doctrine appeared which challenges everybody and asserts that neither likeness nor image nor appearance exists at all, because falsehood never exists anywhere in any way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now, since the existence of false speech and false opinion has been proved, it is possible for imitations of realities to exist and for an art of deception to arise from this condition of mind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is possible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we decided some time ago that the sophist was in one of those two divisions of the image-making class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us try again; let us divide in two the class we have taken up for discussion, and proceed always by way of the right-hand part of the thing divided, clinging close to the company to which the sophist belongs, until, having stripped him of all common properties and left him only his own peculiar nature, we shall show him plainly first to ourselves and secondly to those who are most closely akin to the dialectic method.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We began by making two divisions of art, the productive and the acquisitive, did we not?See Plat. Theaet. 219

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the sophist showed himself to us in the arts of hunting, contests, commerce, and the like, which were subdivisions of acquisitive art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now, since imitative art has taken him over, it is clear that our first step must be the division of productive art into two parts; for imitative art is a kind of production—of images, however, we say, not of real things in each case. Do you agree?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us first assume two parts of productive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The divine and the human.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I don't yet understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We said, if we remember the beginning of our conversation, that every power is productive which causes things to come into being which did not exist before.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we remember.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: There are all the animals, and all the plants that grow out of the earth from seeds and roots, and all the lifeless substances, fusible and infusible, that are formed within the earth. Shall we say that they came into being, not having been before, in any other way than through God's workmanship? Or, accepting the commonly expressed belief—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What belief?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That nature brings them forth from some self-acting cause, without creative intelligence. Or shall we say that they are created by reason and by divine knowledge that comes from God?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I, perhaps because I am young, often change from one opinion to the other; but now, looking at you and considering that you think they are created by God, I also adopt that view.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well said, Theaetetus; and if I thought you were one of those who would think differently by and by, I should try now, by argument and urgent persuasion, to make you agree with my opinion; but since I understand your nature and see that it of itself inclines, without any words of mine, towards that to which you say you are at present attracted, I will let that go; for it would be a waste of time. But I will assume that things which people call natural are made by divine art, and things put together by man out of those as materials are made by human art, and that there are accordingly two kinds of art, the one human and the other divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now that there are two, divide each of them again.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You divided all productive art widthwise, as it were, before; now divide it lengthwise.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Assume that it is done.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In that way we now get four parts in all; two belong to us and are human, and two belong to the gods and are divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again, when the section is made the other way, one part of each half has to do with the making of real things, and the two remaining parts may very well be called image-making; and so productive art is again divided into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell me again how each part is distinguished.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We know that we and all the other animals, and fire, water, and their kindred elements, out of which natural objects are formed, are one and all the very offspring and creations of God, do we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And corresponding to each and all of these there are images, not the things themselves, which are also made by superhuman skill.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The appearances in dreams, and those that arise by day and are said to be spontaneous—a shadow when a dark object interrupts the firelight, or when twofold light, from the objects themselves and from outside, meets on smooth and bright surfaces and causes upon our senses an effect the reverse of our ordinary sight, thus producing an image.This was the current explanation of reflection. Mirrors and smooth objects were supposed to contain a luminous principle which met on the smooth surface with the light coming from the object reflected. So in the act of vision the fire within the eye united with the external fire (Plat. Tim. 46a). The words TH=S E)/MPROSQEN . . . E)NANTI/AN AI)/SQHSIN refer to the transposition of right and left in the reflection (cf. Plat. Theaet. 193c).

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, these are two works of divine creation, the thing itself and the corresponding image in each case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about our own art? Shall we not say that we make a house by the art of building, and by the art of painting make another house, a sort of man-made dream produced for those who are awake?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in the same way, we say, all the other works of our creative activity also are twofold and go in pairs—the thing itself, produced by the art that creates real things, and the image, produced by the image-making art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I understand better now; and I agree that there are two kinds of production, each of them twofold—the divine and the human by one method of bisection, and by the other real things and the product that consists of a sort of likenesses.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must remember that there were to be two parts of the image-making class, the likeness-making and the fantastic, if we should find that falsehood really existed and was in the class of real being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, there were.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we found that falsehood does exist, and therefore we shall now, without any doubts, number the kinds of image-making art as two, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, again bisect the fantastic art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One kind is that produced by instruments, the other that in which the producer of the appearance offers himself as the instrument.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When anyone, by employing his own person as his instrument, makes his own figure or voice seem similar to yours, that kind of fantastic art is called mimetic.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, classify this part under the name of mimetic art; but as for all the rest, let us be so self-indulgent as to let it go and leave it for someone else to unify and name appropriately.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well, let us adopt that classification and let the other part go.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it is surely worth while to consider, Theaetetus, that the mimetic art also has two parts; and I will tell you why.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Please do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Some who imitate do so with knowledge of that which they imitate, and others without such knowledge. And yet what division can we imagine more complete than that which separates knowledge and ignorance?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The example I just gave was of imitation by those who know, was it not? For a man who imitates you would know you and your figure.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what of the figure of justice and, in a word, of virtue in general? Are there not many who have no knowledge of it, but only a sort of opinion, and who try with the greatest eagerness to make this which they themselves think is virtue seem to exist within them, by imitating it in acts and words to the best of their ability?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, there are very many such people.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do all of them, then, fail in the attempt to seem to be just when they are not so at all? Or is quite the opposite the case?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite the opposite.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then I think we must say that such an imitator is quite distinct from the other, the one who does not know from the one who knows.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Where, then, can the fitting name for each of the two be found? Clearly it is not an easy task, because there was, it seems, among the earlier thinkers a long established and careless indolence in respect to the division of classes or genera into forms or species, so that nobody even tried to make such divisions; therefore there cannot be a great abundance of names. However, even though the innovation in language be a trifle bold, let us, for the sake of making a distinction, call the imitation which is based on opinion, oplnion-imitation, and that which is founded on knowledge, a sort of scientific imitation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We mat therefore apply ourselves to the former, for we found that the sophist was among those who imitate but was not among those who know.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us examine the opinion-imitator as if he were a piece of iron, and see whether he is sound or there is still some seam in him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Let us do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, there is a very marked seam. For some of these imitators are simple-minded and think they know that about which they have only opinion, but the other kind because of their experience in the rough and tumble of arguments, strongly suspect and fear that they are ignorant of the things which they pretend before the public to know.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly the two classes you mention both exist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we call one the simple imitator and the other the dissembling imitator?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is reaonable, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And shall we say that the latter forms one class or two again?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is your affair.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am considering, and I think I can see two classes I see one who can dissemble in long speeches in public before a multitude, and the other who does it in private in short speeches and forces the person who converses with him to contradict himself.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what name shall we give to him who makes the longer speeches? Statesman or popular orator?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Popular orator.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what shall we call the other? Philosopher or sophist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We cannot very well call him philosopher, since by our hypothesis he is ignorant; but since he is all imitator of the philosopher, he will evidently have a name derived from his, and I think I am sure at last that we must truly call him the absolutely real and actual sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we then bind up his name as we did before, winding it up from the end to the beginning?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The imitative kind of the dissembling part of the art of opinion which is part of the art of contradiction and belongs to the fantastic class of the image-making art, and is not divine, but human, and has been defined in arguments as the juggling part of productive activity—he who says that the true sophist is of this descent and blood will, in my opinion, speak the exact truth.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, he certainly will.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Really I am greatly indebted to you, Theodorus, for my acquaintance with Theaetetus and with the Stranger, too.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: Presently, Socrates, you will be three times as much indebted, when they have worked out the statesman and the philosopher for you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Indeed! My dear Theodorus, can I believe my ears? Were those really the words of the great calculator and geometrician?

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: Why, what do you mean, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When you rated sophist, statesman, and philosopher at the same value, though they are farther apart in worth than your mathematical proportion can express.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p:
By Ammon, our special divinity,Theodorus was from Cyrene, not far from the oasis of Ammon. that is a good hit, Socrates; evidently you havent forgotten your mathematics, and you are quite right in, finding fault with my bad arithmetic. I will get even with you at some other time; but now, Stranger, I turn to you. Do not grow tired of being kind to us, but go on and tell us about the statesman or the philosopher,
whichever you prefer to take first.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is the thing to do, Theodorus, since we have once begun, and we must not stop until we have finished with them. But what shall I do about Theaetetus here?

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: In what respect?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we give him a rest and take his schoolmate here, the young Socrates, in his place? What is your advice?

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: Make the change as you suggest. They are young, and if they have a chance to rest by turns, they will bear any labor better.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And besides, Stranger, it seems to me that they are both related to me after a fashion; one of them anyhow, as you say, looks like me in his cast of countenance, and the other has the same name and appellation, which implies some sort of kinship. Of course we ought always to be eager to get acquainted with our relatives by debating with them. Now I myself had an argument with Theaetetus yesterday and have been listening to his answers just now, but I do not know Socrates in either way and must examine him, too. But let him reply to you now; my turn will come by and by.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well; Socrates, do you hear what Socrates says?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And do you agree?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: There seems to be no objection on your part, and I suppose there should be still less on mine. Well, then, after the sophist, I think it is our next duty to seek for the statesman; so please tell me: should we rank him also among those who have a science, or not?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Must the sciences, then, be divided as when we were examining the sophist?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In that case, Socrates, I think the division will not be along the same lines.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How will it be?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Along other lines.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Where, then, shall we find the statesmans path? For we must find it, separate it from the rest, and imprint upon it the seal of a single class; then we must set the mark of another single class upon all the other paths that lead away from this, and make our soul conceive of all sciences as of two classes.i.e. one class is to be separated and then all the rest are to be marked as one other class—the familiar division into two parts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: This, Stranger, is now your affair, I think, not mine.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet, Socrates, it must be your affair, too, when we have found the path.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Quite true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Are not arithmetic and certain other kindred arts pure sciences, without regard to practical application, which merely furnish knowledge?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, they are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the science possessed by the arts relating to carpentering and to handicraft in general is inherent in their application, and with its aid they create objects which did not previously exist.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In this way, then, divide all science into two arts, calling the one practical, and the other purely intellectual.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Let us assume that all science is one and that these are its two forms.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we then assume that the statesman, king, master, and householder too, for that matter, are all one, to be grouped under one title, or shall we say that there are as many arts as names? But let me rather help you to understand in this way.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By this example: If anyone, though himself in private station, is able to advise one of the public physicians, must not his art be called by the same name as that of the man whom he advises?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, if a man who is himself in private station is wise enough to advise him who is king of a country, shall we not say that he has the science which the ruler himself ought to possess?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: We shall.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But certainly the science of a true king is kingly science?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And will not he who possesses this science, whether he happen to be a ruler or a private citizen, rightly be called “kingly,” when considered purely with reference to his art?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: At least he has a right to be.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely the householder and the master of a family are the same.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, so far as government is concerned, is there any difference between the grandeur of a large house and the majesty of a small state?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then as for the point we were just discussing, it is clear that all these are the objects of one science, and whether a man calls this the art of kingship or statesmanship or householding, let us not quarrel with him.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But this is plain, that any king can do little with his hands or his whole body toward holding his position, compared with what he can do with the sagacity and strength of his soul.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, that is plain.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we say, then, that the king is more akin to the intellectual than to the manual or the practical in general?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we, therefore, put all these together as one—the political art and the statesman, the royal art and the king?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Obviously.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we should be proceeding in due order if we should next divide intellectual science?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now pay attention to see if we can perceive any natural line of cleavage in it.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Tell us of what sort it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of this sort. We recognized a sort of art of calculation.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is, I suppose, most certainly one of the intellectual arts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And shall we grant to the art of calculation, when it has found out the difference between numbers, any further function than that of passing judgement on them when found out?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Every architect, too, is a ruler of workmen, not a workman himself.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: As supplying knowledge, not manual labor.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So he may fairly be said to participate in intellectual science.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it is his business, I suppose, not to pass judgement and be done with it and go away, as the calculator did, but to give each of the workmen the proper orders, until they have finished their appointed task.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then all such sciences, and all those that are in the class with calculating, are alike intellectual sciences, but these two classes differ from one another in the matter of judging and commanding. Am I right?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then if we bisected intellectual science as a whole and called one part the commanding and the other the judging part, might we say we had made fitting division?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely when men are doing anything in common it is pleasant for them to agree.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: On this point, then, so long as we ourselves are in agreement, we need not bother about the opinions of others.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now to which of these two classes is the kingly man to be assigned? Shall we assign him to the art of judging, as a kind of spectator, or rather to the art of commanding, inasmuch as he is a ruler?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Rather to the latter, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then once more we must see whether the art of command falls into two divisions. It seems to me that it does, and I think there is much the same distinction between the kingly class and the class of heralds as between the art of men who sell what they themselves produce and that of retail dealers.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Retail dealers receive and sell over again the productions of others, which have generally been sold before.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in like manner heralds receive the purposes of others in the form of orders, and then give the orders a second time to others.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p:
Shall we, then, join the art of the king in the same class with the art of the interpreter, the boatswain, the prophet, the herald, and many other kindred arts, all of which involve giving orders? Or, as we just now made a comparison of functions, shall we now by comparison make a name also—since the class of those who issue orders of their own is virtually nameless—and assign kings to the science of giving orders of ones own, disregarding all the rest and leaving to someone else the task of naming them? For the object of our present quest is the ruler,
not his opposite.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since a reasonable distinction between this class and the rest has been made, by distinguishing the commands given as ones own or anothers, shall we again divide this class, if there is in it any further line of section?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think there is one; please help me in making the section.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: On what line?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Take the case of all those whom we conceive of as rulers who give commands: shall we not find that they all issue commands for the sake of producing something?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Furthermore it is not at all difficult to divide all that is produced into two classes.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of the whole class, some have life and others have no life.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And on these same lines we may, if we like, make a division of the part of intellectual science which commands.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By assigning one part of it to the production of lifeless, the other to that of living objects; and in this way the whole will be divided into two parts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us then leave one half and take up the other, and then let us divide that entire half into two parts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Which half shall we take up?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which issues commands relating to living objects, assuredly. For certainly the science of the king is not, like that of the architect, one which supervises lifeless objects; it is a nobler science, since it exercises its power among living beings and in relation to them alone.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now you may notice that the breeding and nurture of living beings is sometimes the nurture of a single animal and sometimes the common care of creatures in droves.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we shall find that the statesman is not one who tends a single creature, like the driver of a single ox or the groom who tends a horse; he has more resemblance to a man who tends a herd of cattle or a drove of horses.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That seems to be true, now that you mention it.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we call the art of caring for many living creatures the art of tending a herd or something like community management?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Whichever we happen to say.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Good, Socrates! If you preserve this attitude of indifference to mere names, you will turn out richer in wisdom when you are old. But now we will, as you suggest, not trouble ourselves about the name; but do you see a way in which a man may show that the art of herding is twofold, and may thereby cause that which is now sought among a double number of things to be sought among half as many?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: I am quite willing to try. I think one kind is the care of men, the other that of beasts.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You made the division with perfect willingness and courage. However, let us do our best not to fall again into your error.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What error?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must not take a single small part, and set it off against many large ones, nor disregard species in making our division. On the contrary, the part must be also a species. It is a very fine thing to separate the object of our search at once from everything else, if the separation can be made correctly, and so, just now, you thought you had the right division and you hurried our discussion along, because you saw that it was leading towards man. But, my friend, it is not safe to whittle off shavings; it is safer to proceed by cutting through the middle, and in that way one is more likely to find classes. This makes all the difference in the conduct of research.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean by that, Stranger?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I must try to speak still more clearly, Socrates, out of regard for your capacity. Just at present it is impossible to make the matter entirely plain, but I will try to lay it before you a little more fully for the sake of clearness.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What is it, then, that you say we did wrongly in making our division just now?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It was very much as if, in undertaking to divide the human race into two parts, one should make the division as most people in this country do; they separate the Hellenic race from all the rest as one, and to all the other races, which are countless in number and have no relation in blood or language to one another, they give the single name “barbarian”; then, because of this single name, they think it is a single species. Or it was as if a man should think he was dividing number into two classes by cutting off a myriad from all the other numbers, with the notion that he was making one separate class, and then should give one name to all the rest, and because of that name should think that this also formed one class distinct from the other. A better division, more truly classified and more equal, would be made by dividing number into odd and even, and the human race into male and female; as for the Lydians and Phrygians and various others they could be opposed to the rest and split off from them when it was impossible to find and separate two parts, each of which formed a class.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very true; but thats just the trouble, Stranger: how can we get a clearer knowledge of class and part, and see that they are not the same thing, but different?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Socrates, you most excellent young man, it is no small task you impose upon me. We have already strayed away from our subject more than we ought, and you wish us to wander still farther afield. So for the present let us return to our subject, as is proper; then we will go on the trail of this other matter by and by, when we have time. Only take very good care not to imagine that you ever heard me declare flatly—

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That class and part are separate from one another.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: But what did you say?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That when there is a class of anything, it must necessarily be a part of the thing of which it is said to be a class; but there is no necessity that a part be also a class. Please always give this, rather than the other, as my doctrine.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: I will do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then please go on to the next point.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That from which our present digression started. For I think it started when you were asked how the art of herding should be divided and said with great readiness that there were two kinds of living beings, the human race and a second one, a single class, comprising all the beasts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it was clear to me at the time that you removed a part and then thought that the remainder was one class because you were able to call them all by the same name of beasts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is true, too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But indeed, my most courageous young friend, perhaps, if there is any other animal capable of thought, such as the crane appears to be, or any other like creature, and it perchance gives names, just as you do, it might in its pride of self oppose cranes to all other animals, and group the rest, men included, under one head, calling them by one name, which might very well be that of beasts. Now let us try to be on our guard against all that sort of thing.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How can we guard against it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By not dividing the whole class of living beings, that so we may avoid such errors.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Well, there is no need of dividing the whole.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No, certainly not, for it was in that way that we fell into our former error.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That part of intellectual science which involves giving commands was a part of our animal-tending class, with especial reference to animals in herds, was it not?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, even at that stage of our discussion all animals had already been divided into tame and wild. For if their nature admits of domestication they are called tame; if it does not, they are called wild.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the science we are hunting for was, and is, to be sought among tame creatures, more specifically creatures in herds.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, not make our division as we did before, with a view to all, nor in a hurry, with the idea that we may thus reach political science quickly, for that has already brought upon us the proverbial penalty.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What penalty?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The penalty of having made less speed, because we made too much haste and did not make our division right.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: And it was a good thing for us, Stranger

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I do not deny it. So let us begin again and try to divide the art of tending animals in common; for perhaps the information you desire so much will come to you in the ordinary course of our conversation better than by other means. Tell me—

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whether, as I suppose, you have often heard people speak of this,— for I know you never actually saw the preserves of fish in the Nile and in the ponds of the Persian king. But perhaps you have noticed the like in fountain-pools.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I have often seen the fish in fountain-pools and have heard many tales of those foreign preserves.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely, even if you have not wandered over the plains of Thessaly, you have heard of goose-farms and crane-farms there and you believe that they exist.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The reason why I asked you all these questions is that the rearing of flocks is in part aquatic and in part an affair of the dry land.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then do you agree that we ought to divide the art of tending animals in common into corresponding parts, assigning one part of it to each of these two, and calling one the art of aquatic-herding and the other the art of land-herding?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I agree.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely we shall not have to ask to which of these two arts kingship belongs, for that is clear to everyone.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Anybody could doubtless make a division of the art of tending herds on land.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What would the division be?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Into the tending of flying and walking animals.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And statesmanship is to be sought in connection with walking animals, is it not? Any fool, so to speak, would believe that, dont you think?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the art of tending animals that walk must, like an even number, be divided in half.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And now I think I see two paths leading in that direction in which our argument has started: the quicker way, by separating a relatively small part and a larger, and the other way, which is more in accord with what we said a while ago about the need of making the division as nearly in the middle as we can, but is longer. So we can proceed by whichever of the two we wish.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Can we not go by both?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Not by both at once, silly boy; but obviously we can take them in turn.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Then I choose both in turn.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is easy enough, since we have but a short distance to go. At the beginning, certainly, or middle of our journey it would have been hard to comply with your demand. But now, since this is your wish, let us go first by the longer way, for we are fresher now and shall get along on it more easily. So attend to the division.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The tame walking animals which live in herds are divided by nature into two classes.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How by nature?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because one class is naturally without horns, and the other has horns.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is obvious.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now divide the art of tending herds of walking animals into two parts, assigning one to each class of animals; and define the parts, for if you try to give them names, the matter will become needlessly complicated.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How shall I speak of them then?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In this way: say that the science which tends herds of walking animals is divided into two parts, one of which is assigned to the horned portion of the herd, the other to the hornless portion.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Assume that I have said that; for you have made it perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And furthermore our “king” is very clearly the herdsman of a herd devoid of horns.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course; that is evident.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us then try to break up this herd and give the king the part that belongs to him.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we make our division on the basis of having or not having cloven hoofs, or on that of mixing or not mixing the breed? You know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No. What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Why, I mean that horses and asses can breed from each other.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Oh yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the rest of the herd of hornless tame animals cannot cross the breed.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is true, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, does the statesman appear to have charge of a kind that mixes or of one that does not mix the breed?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Evidently of one that is unmixed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So I suppose we must proceed as we have done heretofore and divide this into two parts.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, we must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet tame gregarious animals have all, with the exception of about two species, been already divided; for dogs are not properly to be counted among gregarious creatures.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No, they are not. But how shall we divide the two species?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: As you and Theaetetus ought by rights to divide them, since you are interested in geometry.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By the diameter, of course, and again by the diameter of the square of the diameter.The word “diameter” here denotes the diagonal of a square. The early Greek mathematicians worked out their arithmetical problems largely by geometrical methods (cf. Plat. Theaet. 147 D ff). The diagonal of the unit square (√2) was naturally of especial interest. It was called sometimes, as here simply H( DIA/METROS, sometimes, as just below,H( DIA/METROS H( DUNA/MEI DI/POUS, or, more briefly,H( DIA/METROS DI/POUS. Given a square the side of which is the unit (i.e. one square foot), the length of the diagonal will be √2 and the square constructed with that diagonal as its side will contain two square feet. The length of the diagonal of this square will be √4=2 feet, and its area will be four square feet.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is the nature which our human race possesses related to walking in any other way than as the diameter which is the square root of two feet?There is here a play upon words. Man, being a two-footed (DI/POUS) animal, is compared to the diagonal of the unit square (√2,DIA/METROS DI/POUS).

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the nature of the remaining species, again, considered from the point of view of the square root, is the diameter of the square of our root, if it is the nature of twice two feet.i.e. the remaining species is four-footed. Our diameter is √2, and four is the area of the square constructed on the diagonal of the square which has √2 as its side. All this satirizes the tendency of contemporary thinkers to play with numbers.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course; and now I think I almost understand what you wish to make plain.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Socrates, do we see that besides this something else has turned up in these divisions of ours which would be a famous joke?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: No. What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Our human race shares the same lot and runs in the same heat as the most excellent and at the same time most easy-going race of creatures.The animal referred to is the pig. See P. Shorey, Classical Philology,1917, July, p. 308.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I see that; it is a very queer result.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Indeed? But is it not reasonable that they arrive last, who are the slowest?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, that is true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And do we fail to notice this further point, that the king appears in a still more ridiculous light, running along with the herd and paired in the race with the man of all others who is most in training for a life of careless ease?i.e. the swineherd, the pig belonging to GE/NEI EU)XERESTA/TW|.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Certainly he does.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For now, Socrates, we have shown more clearly the truth of that which we said yesterday in our search for the sophist.See Plat. Soph. 227B.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That this method of argument pays no more heed to the noble than to the ignoble, and no less honor to the small than to the great, but always goes on its own way to the most perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall I now, without waiting for you to ask me, guide you of my own accord along that shorter way referred to a moment ago that leads to the definition of the king?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I say, then, that we ought at that time to have divided walking animals immediately into biped and quadruped, then seeing that the human race falls into the same division with the feathered creatures and no others, we must again divide the biped class into featherless and feathered, and when that division is made and the art of herding human beings is made plain, we ought to take the statesmanlike and kingly man and place him as a sort of charioteer therein, handing over to him the reins of the state, because that is his own proper science.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: You have cleared up the argument finely, and as if it were a debt you were paying, you threw in the digression as interest and for good measure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us go back to the beginning and join together the definition of the name of the statesmans art link by link to the end.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet, Socrates, have we truly accomplished this, exactly as you have said?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Accomplished what?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The perfectly satisfactory discussion of our subject. Or is our investigation incomplete in just this detail, that we have given a definition after a fashion, but have not perfectly completed it?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I will try to make still plainer to us both the thought which I now have in mind.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Please do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We found just now that there were many arts of herding, and one of them was the art of statesmanship, which was the care of one particular kind of herd, did we not?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And our argument defined this, not as the tending of horses or other beasts, but as the science of tending men in common.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, it did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, observe the point of difference between kings and all other herdsmen.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What point of difference?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us see whether anyone who is designated by the name of another art says and claims that he is fellow manager of the herd in common with any of the other kinds of herdsmen.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For instance, merchants, husbandmen, and all who prepare grain for use, and also gymnastic trainers and physicians would certainly all dispute with the herdsmen of humanity, whom we have called statesmen, and would assert that they themselves take care of the tending of humanity, and not the tending of the common herd only, but even that of the rulers themselves, would they not?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: And would they be right?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps. We will examine that matter; but this we know, that no one will ever raise such a contention against any neatherd, but the herdsman himself tends the herd, he is their physician, he is their matchmaker, and he alone knows the midwifes science of aiding at the birth of their offspring. Moreover, so far as the nature of the creatures allows them to enjoy sport or music, no one can enliven or soothe them better than he; whether with instruments or merely with his voice he performs the music best suited to his own herd; and the same applies to the other herdsmen. Is not that the case?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: You are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then how can our discourse about the king be right and free from error, when we pick him out alone as herdsman and tender of the human herd, while countless others dispute his claim?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: It cannot possibly be right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We suspected a little while ago that although we might be outlining a sort of kingly shape we had not yet perfected an accurate portrait of the statesman, and could not do so until, by removing those who crowd about him and contend with him for a share in his herdsmanship, we separated him from them and made him stand forth alone and uncontaminated. Was our fear justified?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: It certainly was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must attend to that, Socrates, if we are not to end our argument in disgrace.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: But we certainly must not do that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must begin again from a new sarting-point and travel by a different road.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: By what road?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By one which offers us some amusement; for there is a famous story a great part of which it is really our duty to insert into our discussion; and then after that we can proceed as before, by eliminating part after part, and in that way reach the ultimate object of our search. Shall we do that?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then please pay careful attention to my story, just as if you were a child; and anyway you are not much too old for childrens tales.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Please tell the story.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of the portents recorded in ancient tales many did happen and will happen again. Such an one is the portent connected with the tale of the quarrel between Atreus and Thyestes. You have doubtless heard of it and remember what is said to have taken place.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: You refer, I suppose, to the token of the golden lamb.Hermes revenged upon the Pelopidae the death of his son Myrtilus by causing a lamb with golden fleece to be born among the flocks of Atreus. When his claim to the succession was disputed, Atreus promised to show this prodigy to prove that the gods were on his side. Thyestes persuaded Aerope, the wife of Atreus, to give him the lamb, and Atreus was in danger of losing his kingdom, had not Zeus, who favored his claim, made the sun and the Pleiades return from their setting towards their rising. This is the form of the story given in a scholium on Eur. Orest. 988, and Plato seems to have this form in mind, though variants existed. The lamb was a token (SHMEI=ON) of the favor of the gods, and the changed course of the sun and stars was a testimony (MARTURH/SAS) to the right of Atreus.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Oh no; I mean the change in the rising and setting of the sun and the other heavenly bodies, how in those times they used to set in the quarter where they now rise, and used to rise where they now set, but the god at the time of the quarrel, you recall, changed all that to the present system as a testimony in favor of Atreus.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, Ive heard that, too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again we have often heard the tale of the reign of Cronus.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about the story that the ancient folk were earthborn and not begotten of one another?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is one of the old tales, too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, all these stories and others still more remarkable have their source in one and the same event, but in the lapse of ages some of them have been lost and others are told in fragmentary and disconnected fashion. But no one has told the event which is the cause of them all, and so I must tell it now; for that will help us to make clear the nature of the king.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Very good; just tell your tale and omit nothing.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Listen then. During a certain period God himself goes with the universe as guide in its revolving course, but at another epoch, when the cycles have at length reached the measure of his allotted time, he lets it go, and of its own accord it turns backward in the opposite direction, since it is a living creature and is endowed with intelligence by him who fashioned it in the beginning. Now this reversal of its motion is an inevitable part of its nature for the following reason.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: What reason?

sp.speaker: Stranger
Younger Socrates
sp.p: All that account of yours appears, at any rate, very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, in the light of what has been said, let us consider and gain understanding of the event which we said was the cause of all those wonderful portents; for it is really just this.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Just what?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The fact that at certain periods the universe has its present circular motion, and at other periods it revolves in the reverse direction.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: How was this the cause?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We cannot help believing that of all the changes which take place in the heavens this reversal is the greatest and most complete.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: It certainly seems to be so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore we must also believe that at the same time the greatest changes come upon us who dwell within the heavens.

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: That is likely too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And animals cannot well endure many great and various changes at once. That is a familiar fact, is it not?

sp.speaker: Younger Socrates
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Inevitably, then, there is at that time great destruction of animals in general, and only a small part of the human race survives; and the survivors have many experiences wonderful and strange, the greatest of which, a consequence of the reversal of everything at the time when the world begins to turn in the direction opposed to that of its present revolution, is this.The tale of Atreus introduces the fanciful theory of the reversal of the revolution of the heavenly bodies, and this, especially in an age when the stars were believed to exercise a direct influence upon mankind and other creatures, naturally brings with it the reversal of all processes of growth. This leads to a new birth of mankind, and the Stranger then briefly describes the age of innocence, the fall of man and the barbarism that follows, and the partial restoration of man through divine interposition and the gift of the various arts of civilization. Plato does not offer this as a real explanation of the existing condition of the world, but it serves, like the myths introduced in other dialogues to present, in connection with accepted mythology, a theory which may account for some of the facts of life.
